There are various agencies that display mapping data, but the two mayor providers would be the Instituto Geográfico Nacional (1) and the Instituto Nacional de Estadística y Censos (2).

(2): http://www.indec.mecon.ar/

column15:
There is a quantity of statistical datasets in Argentina collected by the Instituto Nacional de Estadística y Censos (1). Even though these data in not available in open formats. Some economical datasets have been observed more than once by international institutions such as the International Monetary Fund. In this case the IMF has issued a declaration of censorship and called on Argentina to adopt remedial measures to address the quality of official GDP and consumer price index data.

##Sources:

(1): http://www.indec.mecon.ar

There is data on government spend at the Oficina Nacional de Presupuesto, that has place in the Secretaría de Hacienda, a part of the Ministerio de Economía y Finanzas Públicas.

The Instituto Nacional de Estadística y Censos counts with more detailed data, according to the categories determined by the law of budget.

column15: Theres is a lot of data collected but a great part of it is not shared, or in some cases it is accessible internally. There is a Unity of Monitoring within the Subsecretaría del Comercio Exterior (Ministerio de Economía y Finanzas Públicas) that has the legal mandate of providing updated information on foreign trade to different areas of the Ministry of Foreign Trade. In fact it mentions they have developed various tech tools for information management, allowing easy and dynamic access to data on foreign trade within the Secretariat and other areas of the Ministry. It produces some data that is shared through the Instituto Nacional de Estadística y Censos as reports.

column15:
There is some data on health services on the Sistema Integrado de Información Sanitaria Argentino (Ministerio de Salud), however to access it, an authorization is needed. There Argentinian Open Data portal provides some outdated datasets. The Ministry of Health provides a Unified Information System of Health Data (2) but most of its features requires a user/password. The Ministerio de Salud also has some data on some basic indicators (3), but the last publication on those date from 2012.

column15:
There are databases collected from different governmental institutions. On one hand there are all the provincial authorities of the Dirección Nacional de Política Criminal (Ministerio de Justicia), which inform and produce a national database. This data refers to certain types of crimes and in not up to date (last report dates from 2012).

There are also some databases produced by government and shared between public bodies in charge of security but not publicly. This is the case of the Dirección Nacional de Gestión de la Información Criminal (Ministerio de Seguridad)

column15:
There is environmental statistics data available, but the most part of it, even if it is shared, in not updated. The principal responsible for this type of data is the Dirección de Impacto Ambiental y Social (1), part of the Secretaría Ambiente y Desarrollo Sustentable de la Nación. They have various statistic (not updated) and they have developed the Sistema de Indicadores de Desarrollo Sostenible, but even these are out of date.

There is also some of these data, in the national level, in the hands of the Ministerio de Agricultura, Ganadería y Pesca (2) and at the Subsecretaría de Recursos Hídricos, but the latter asks for personal information in order to provide the data (3). Also at the provincial level there are the environmental or sustainable development offices that owe their own data.

(1): http://www.ambiente.gov.ar/?idseccion=16
(2): http://www.siia.gov.ar/_apps/siia/arbol/total_pciaX.php?respuesta=M
(3): http://bdhi.hidricosargentina.gov.ar/sitioweb/frmInicial.aspx

(6): Subsecretaría de Recursos hídricos, http://www.hidricosargentina.gov.ar/ Accessed on September 29th, 2014

column15:
Geoscience Australia's National Geographic Information Group is the Australian Government's National Mapping Agency. 

Department of Communications that opened up  ‘National Map Open Data’ initiative, which aims to give users access to a single platform for Government geospatial datasets, including those from the Bureau of Meteorology, Australian Bureau of Statistics and data.gov.au.

The Australian Bureau of Statistics looks after statistical geography. 

The Department of Infrastructure and Regional Development keeps data on roads and related infrastructure.
column18: The Maps have various information that includes such as official administrative borders, roads and other important infrastructure - railways, land tenure, maritime zones, etc
column20: Open data is available freely through the government however some third party organisations offer data set visualisation (though they retrieve the original data from the government).
column24: Map data is also available on Open data website - http://nationalmap.nicta.com.au/
column26: Data can be accessed through bulk web services.
column27: The Map data sets can freely be accessed from the agencies that are responsible for map data.
column29: Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Australia
column34: Data is sustainable. There is a range of Map data and Maps of different features from the agencies responsible for publishing data.
column35:
Data can easily be discovered on the Geoscience Australia websites and the Open data portal - http://data.gov.au/.

Also, on the Open data portal - http://data.gov.au/ , there is a link to National Map - http://nationalmap.nicta.com.au/

column15:
Australian Bureau of Statistics

The Australian Government is responsible for the release of the national statistics dataset and there is opportunity to request more data via data.gov.au data request site. These data sets are collated from the Australian Bureau of Statistics as well as local data (as census data is published retrospectively after the data has been collected).
column18: The national statistics on the Australian Bureau of Statistics includes information on population and housing characteristics of the people in the country. Data includes information on education levels, marital status, religious affiliations, employment, housing, among others
column20: Open data is available freely through the government however some third party organisations offer data set visualisation (though they retrieve the original data from the government).

(4) extensive population data by education
(4.1) Example: 
Population by highest completed education (ISCED-97 levels), sex and provinces, 2012
column26:
A direct and easy download is not available. The database exploration tool is painful and would involve clicking oneself to death in order to get "all". (1)

(1) http://statcube.at/superweb/login.do?guest=guest
column29: Re-use allowed, but only "appropriate" use.
column34: The statistical office regularly provides and updates data, available data ranges far back. Bulk possibilities missing, interface for accessing the database, open data area still _very_ basic.
column35: clicking through the statistics area works pretty easy.

column15: Bundesministerium der Finanzen (Federal Ministry of Finances)
column18:
The national budget is not available in an open form. On the other hand, Austria's communities are publishing their budgets via a joint technical platform (2), so 600 of about 2400 communities are providing transparent and visualised data.

The Ministry of Finances has yet only published one open dataset at all, which is a list of all tax offices.
column24:
(1) Budget 2014/15 overview site
(1a) example for tables from budget report (came into effect as law)

The granularity of the federal Budget is rather low, the largest files are about 400 K big, individual sheets within files are rarely larger than 100 rows. Essentially directly taken out of the Budget in PDF form. The detailed bugdet is only available as PDF (1)

(1) Overview: https://service.bmf.gv.at/BUDGET/Budgets/2014_2015/bfg2014/teilhefte/_start_teilhefte.htm
(2) Example Interior: https://service.bmf.gv.at/BUDGET/Budgets/2014_2015/bfg2014/teilhefte/UG11/UG11_Verzeichnis_veranschlagter_Konten_2014.pdf
column26: Ranging back to 2012, no bulk possibilities
column29: No direct disclaimer, only on website's imprint: "Protected by copyright. All rights are reserved. Except for commercial purposes, reproduction is at the source is acknowledged."
column34: To some extent yes, as data excerpt are regularly published, also with the xlsx documents. On the other hand, the details are only published as PDF, so the really interesting parts of the budget cannot be be approached by machines.
column35: Yes, via preliminary WI research and OD Index.

column15: Federal Ministry of Finance
column18:
Again, Open Spending delivers spending details (1) as well as an breakdown on how taxes are spent (2), whereas the Federal Ministry of Finance delivers data, but not in a re-useable form (3). However, as for the focus of the survey, I will review the federal source.

(1) http://www.offenerhaushalt.at/gemeinde/engerwitzdorf/finanzdaten/hauptansicht (municipal example)
(2) http://www.offenerhaushalt.at/gemeinde/engerwitzdorf/finanzdaten/steuereuro (municipal example)
(3) https://service.bmf.gv.at/budget/akthh/2014/_start.htm

I also cant consider the data under (3) as "Available", because it is highly aggregated (almost always over 1 m €, often 500 m € or even more) and not on a transactional level.

column15:
Company Register Database: Federal Ministry of Justice
Central Business Register: Ministry of Science, Research and Economy
column18:
The "Firmenbuchdatenbank" (Company Register Database) is maintained by the Federal Ministry of Justice. The access has to be paid for (1).
The "Zentrales Gewerberegister" (Central Business Register) is maintained by the Ministry of Science, Research and Economy and is not open either (2).

(1) http://www.justiz.gv.at/web2013/html/default/2c9484852308c2a601240b693e1c0860.de.html
(2) http://www.digitales.oesterreich.gv.at/site/6761/default.aspx#a46

column15: Federal Chancellery (Bundeskanzleramt)
column18:
Federal Law is available in an open form in the Federal application "RIS - Bundesrecht konsolidiert" (1).

Legislative information can also be found at the central resources of the Federal Chancellery, but re-use has to be paid for (2).

(1) http://www.data.gv.at/datensatz/?id=31430a9f-c8ba-4654-ab68-c9c3dff0361b
(2) https://www.ris.bka.gv.at/UI/Info.aspx
column20: A number of apps use the open data provided by the Government, download do not appear to be included.
column22: asmx, xsd, wsdl (web services, return laws in xml)
column24: The consolidated version of Federal Law can be queried and displayed.
column26: I assume that one can download the whole content of the law database via the APIs
column29: No license given, which has to do with the fact that laws cannot be copyright protected in Germany and Austria.
column33: Continually (can be daily, but depends on difficulty of editing)
column34: As it's based on a database that has been published in different editions since 1949, and this is done by the Chancellery, definitely!
column35: Via the OGD portal, search for "bundesrecht" or consult the OD Index

column18:
To a small extent timetable data is available: The OGD portal lists data for the city of Linz (1)
Vienna has data on its own site - I am using it a the reference here (2)
National data by the Österreichische Bundesbahn (Austrian Railways) is not available in an open form, only for Google or as embedded application ("Scotty". (3)
column24: A routing system for the capital city of Vienna, covering the public transport (except private buses). Also available are csvs with stations, lines and coordinates on the platforms (this is required for directing the passengers within the stations)
column26: The available data can be considered as bulk.
column29: CC-BY 3.0 AT
column33: API: real-time; csvs: several times per year
column34: As data is provided in real-time: yes!
column35: Rather easy via OGD portal. However, initial research on availability a bit tedious.

column15: Statistis Austria
column18: Statistik Austria offers a small amount of data in a fully open format. Theses include international trade data.
column24: Euro values ​​of imports and exports by origin and destination countries, annual time series from 2007. 4 csv datasets, 1 with the actual data, one country list, to explaining the headers
column26:
Further data is available under (1), but no bulk possibilities either.

(1) http://www.statistik.at/web_de/statistiken/aussenhandel/index.html
column29: CC-BY 3.0 Austria
column34: Even though the publication of the "open" series only started recently, Statistics Austria is a reliable data provider.
column35: Easy when going via the mini data portal by Statistics Austria. Otherwise via googling "österreich statistik open data"

column15: Austrian Ministry of Health
column18:
A number of performance indexes such as A-IQI (Austrian Inpatient Quality Index) exist (1), but are in the stage of development and data is not available outside of the profession. Other data such as the Austrian Health Information System (ÖGIS) only is available on a paid basis (2). Furthermore, a quality system with a platform for hospitals also exists - however, it is not intended for public access either. (3)

In general, the Austrian Ministry of Health is in charge of such projects.

Statistics Austria features some data, such as on the self-perceived health (4) or healthy years of life (5), but the data is more than eight years old in case (4) and may not be fully used.

(1) http://bmg.gv.at/home/Schwerpunkte/Gesundheitssystem_Qualitaetssicherung/Ergebnisqualitaetsmessung/
(2) http://www.goeg.at/de/OeGIS
(3) https://qbe.goeg.at/
(4) http://www.statistik.at/web_de/statistiken/gesundheit/gesundheitszustand/subjektiver_gesundheitszustand/index.html
(5) http://www.statistik.at/web_de/statistiken/gesundheit/gesundheitszustand/lebenserwartung_in_gesundheit/index.html

column15: For the National Report: Austrian Ministry of Education
column18:
The National Education Report for Austria also includes a number of Excel tables. But these were published in January 2013, technically not in the scope of the Index any more. (1)
Another factor measured is early school leaving, by the Federal Ministry of Education and Women (2). This data is only available in PDF form.
The statistics compiled by the Federal Ministry of Education are also only available as PDF (3).
column24: A vast number of tables, compiled and partly re-calculated by the publisher. Essentially an excerpt form the PDF report found on the site as well.
column26: No further data available.
column29: Restrictive disclaimer at beginning: No part of this report may be used or processed without written approval of the publisher
column33: Every three years, it appears. The first version was published for 2009 in 2010, the version for 2012 in 2013. So the next would be expected for 2015.
column34: Difficult to assess. Publication every third year, however this is a collection of smaller tables, not one big consistent dataset.
column35: It took quite some time, first going for Educational Report ("Bildungsbericht") produced some results.

column15:
Federal Criminal Police (Bundeskriminalamt)
Federal Ministry of the Interior (Bundesministerium für Inneres)
column18:
The Federal Criminal Police Office collects and aggregates data on various crime subjects. Interestingly, only very brief summaries are published under the subject Crime Statistics (Polizeiliche Kriminalstatistik, PKS) (1) - essentially it's a 6 page press release with on big table summing up the annual development in the entire country and the federal states. (2)
However, the statistics overview page (but not the one for 2013) features a link the "Security Report" by the Ministry of the Interior (Sicherheitsbericht 2013; Kriminalitätsbericht - Statistik und Analyse). It contains very many details on reported crimes, also breaking them down on the federal state level, on over 250 PDF pages. (3)
The Criminal Verdict Statistics by Statistics Austria delivers more detail, but only for the whole country, no federal states or even more granular levels such as counties (4).

(1) http://www.bmi.gv.at/cms/BK/publikationen/krim_statistik/Statistiken_2013.aspx
(2) http://www.bmi.gv.at/cms/BK/presse/files/2882013_PK_KrimEntwicklung1HJ2013.pdf
(3) http://www.bmi.gv.at/cms/BMI_Service/SB_2013/03_Kriminalitaetsbericht_2013_Statistik.pdf
(4) http://www.statistik.at/web_de/statistiken/soziales/kriminalitaet/index.html

The further review is focussed on (3), as reported crimes are the first instance of looking at this subject.
column23:
The statistics (1) are not provided under this label (see a), only available as PDF. An additional check for "sicherheitsbericht site:.at filetype:xls" etc. did not provide any results either.

(1) http://www.bmi.gv.at/cms/BMI_Service/SB_2013/03_Kriminalitaetsbericht_2013_Statistik.pdf

column15: Federal Environmental Office (Umweltbundesamt)
column18:
The Federal Environmental Office (Umweltbundesamt) publishes a number of datasets on the national data portal data.gv.at. These include ozone data, various maps, shapes of national parks, an inventory of wetlands and data on biological diversity (1). 
On the site of the Environmental Office, detailed data from air quality monitoring stations can be found (2).

(1) http://www.data.gv.at/suche/?search-term=&katFilter_umwelt=on&top10Filter_Umweltbundesamt+GmbH=on&publisherFilter_Umweltbundesamt+GmbH=on&connection=and&nr=1
(2) http://www.umweltbundesamt.at/umweltsituation/luft/luftguete_aktuell/tgl_bericht/
column19:
(1) http://www.umweltbundesamt.at/umweltsituation/umweltinfo/opendata/oed_luft/ (ozone)
(2) http://www.umweltbundesamt.at/umweltsituation/luft/luftguete_aktuell/tgl_bericht (daily air quality report(s))
(3) http://luft.umweltbundesamt.at/pub/gmap/start.html (map with daily air quality values)
column23: The air quality data by the monitoring stations is not downloadable. The ozone values from the monitoring stations (provided via the (minimal) data portal of the Umweltbundesamt) are hourly mean values, with no possibility of retrieving data lying further back or a bigger time period. Thus this small data portion can not qualify as a dataset here. In particular when compared to the obviously existing database from example 2 in b).

column15: Federal Ministry of the Interior
column18:
The Federal Ministry of the Interior is in charge of election results data for national (1) and European elections (2).

(1) http://www.data.gv.at/datensatz/?id=09716341-2bea-4298-9525-e936d8247d19
(2) http://www.data.gv.at/datensatz/?id=2b10a91b-51d5-4e34-b992-8fd3a3121f0d
column24: Official result of the parliamentary election 2013 - by municipality code
column26: As no datasets have to be combined etc., and the level of granularity is quite high, this dataset also qualifies as bulk.
column29: CC-BY 3.0 Austria
column33: Depending on the election - the last national election was on 2013-09-29. The publication of the dataset in an open form more than 14 days after the election is not so helpful for those who wanted to use such data in the days after the election.
column34: Published in an open form, done so for the national election and the European election after starting with OGD. Publication efforts appear to be reliable.
column35: Easy via the OGD portal.

column15: Bundesbeschaffung (Federal Procurement)
column18:
The "Bundesbeschaffung" publishes tenders, but not in a machine-readable form (1). Its overview of published tenders is not any more helpful, as it requires opening each individual item. Lists of contracts not in 
force any more (2) and of contracts presently in force are available, but without any details about the winning contractor (3).

(1) http://www.bbg.gv.at/lieferanten/ausschreibungen/alle/
(2) http://www.bbg.gv.at/kunden/produkte-vertraege/abgelaufene-vertraege/
(3) http://www.bbg.gv.at/kunden/produkte-vertraege/vertragsliste/
column23: All tenders are published in an online list, clicking onto each call for details is necessary. No machine-readable data possible. Also, the actual processing is handled over an additional site, auftrag.at, which requires registration.

column15:
The map is provided by the GIS Directorate of the Bahraini Central Informatics Organization. The only way to access the data is through forms. A map exists online and is free to view for everyone. 

Data is clearly not open (see 'Agreement' tab): "The data, information and all materials [...] are protected by the Copyright Laws of the Kingdom of Bahrain and by international treaties. It is illegal and strictly prohibited to distribute, publish, offer for sale, license or sublicense, give or redistribute to any other party the Materials in hard copy or digital form without the prior written permission from CIO. All offenders will be sued in a court of law."
column18:
https://www.bahrainlocator.gov.bh/BahrainLocator/
accessed 23 July 2014.
column23: The data is only available through an online Microsoft Silverlight based interface.

column15: The Ministry of Industry and Commerce seems to be responsible for land rental and ownership. With this respect, I assume they collect relevant data. I have not been able to identify more info than the general overview linked to below. The Survey and Land Registration Bureau has a Land Affairs Group which deals with land ownership too. The Bureau's site also appears to provide links to mapping products which are available to purchase. Resolution does not seem to be indicated though, and purchases are available for paper versions only.
column18:
http://www.moic.gov.bh/En/MoIC%20Centers/BahrainInvestorsCenter/BusinessEnv/LandandProperty/Pages/Land%20Ownership.aspx
http://www.moic.gov.bh/En/MoIC%20Centers/BahrainInvestorsCenter/BusinessEnv/LandandProperty/Pages/Land%20and%20Property.aspx

The Survey and Land Registration Bureau website: http://www.slrb.gov.bh/default.aspx
Land registration fees: http://www.slrb.gov.bh/InformationCentre/details.aspx?slrb=dgQUWRtTs0EavdC17ZqEa7N2Dy5OSInhr8iUA5mgFq4=

accessed 23 July 2014.

column15: The Central Informatics Organisation seems to be responsible. The e-Gov Authority (eGA) is supposed to handle the Open Data Portal. It is unclear how possible dataset requests are handled. When attempting to assess data from the Open Data Portal, one is sent to a knoema.com subdomain website where very limited information is available. The Statistics Dept website provides limited information which is not up-to-date.
column19:
http://statistics.gov.bh/
http://bahrain.knoema.com/?lang=en
Request Data: http://www.data.gov.bh/wps/portal/data/!ut/p/c5/04_SB8K8xLLM9MSSzPy8xBz9CP0os3hfR08jT0sTI0t_UwsnA0_XMF8jL4sQQ5MQI6B8pFm8hYGJo6Gnu4G7hb-PmYFnqLune0iol6GBvykB3eEg-_DrB8kb4ACOBvp-Hvm5qfrBqXn6BbkRBlkmjooA8ZRufQ!!/dl3/d3/L2dJQSEvUUt3QS9ZQnZ3LzZfODA0QTFJRzBHMFZMNDBJRkJLSzJPUDIwMDA!/
accessed 23 July 2014.
column21: http://statistics.gov.bh/en/BulkDownload one needs first to select the dataset(s) then the period and the sectors before reaching a page where the data can be downloaded in various formats among which .txt; .csv (.mdb and .dbf are also included).
column24: I am not convinced the Statistics website provides Open Data as there is no mention of the copyright that applies (neither "copyright" nor license is mentioned).
column26: One needs first to select the dataset(s) then the period and the sectors before reaching a page where the data can be downloaded in various formats.
column27: No charging policy was identified, data can simply be visualised and downloaded directly.
column29: There is no mention as for what intellectual property rule applies.
column31: The date depends on the dataset but mainly datasets cover up to 2010 or 2011.
column33: Unknown. My guess is, from the looks of it, that data was just uploaded at some point and that's it. The 'metadata' section of the Statistics website actually leads to a 'dictionary' section which does not really inform on the available datasets. It is thus impossible to verify whether the data is updated after having been uploaded for the first time.
column34: In the current case, the data publication appears to involve just one-­off publication of datasets, without any clearly identified process in place to keep the data updated. For ex., when one searches for 'education', the available dataset for "Number of educational centers" for adults covers 2006-2010. The website is difficult to browse as the only way to do so is by entering keywords in a Search field which seems to privilege the very first keyword only...
column35: The datasets are difficult to find as the only way to do so is by entering keywords in a Search field which seems to privilege the very first keyword only... Thus, if one wants to see which other datasets are available, one needs to click on each page and manually check all the titles. These sometimes contain spelling mistakes (especially true for the English side of the website) and the javascript seems to suffer some random issues as the "Search" field is sometimes broken.

column15: The Ministry of Finances takes care of this. There is just basic information about how the government has decided to evaluate future budget and some brochures in Arabic, but no actual data is available.
column18:
http://www.mof.gov.bh/Categorylist.asp?cType=budget
accessed 23 July 2014.
column23: The data is not available online at all.

column15: The Ministry of Finances is responsible for spending data. Data is available in summary form for fiscal years (e.g., 2012, see link below; following pages compare 2012 and 2011 for various institutions). Data is clearly indicated to be the property of the Ministry of Finance. No data is available on per-month basis.
column18:
http://www.mof.gov.bh/FlippingManual/Budget2011_2012booklet/HTML/index.html#/21/zoomed
accessed 23 July 2014.

column15: The Ministry of Industry and Commerce contains indications on how to register, various legislative frameworks and latest company registrations. It is not clear how to access previous registrations. The Ministry runs a search engine service through which one can browse companies. The Ministry also has a "Latest Company Registration" tab where one can view a given number of registrations, but it is unclear how to view more in the same list format.
column18:
http://www.moic.gov.bh/En/Main/eServices/Commercial%20Registration%20Inquiry/Pages/Commercial%20Registration%20Inquiry.aspx?eserviceID=3
http://www.moic.gov.bh/En/Main/eServices/Latest%20Commercial%20Registrations/Pages/Latest%20Commercial%20Registrations.aspx?eserviceID=6
accessed 23 July 2014.
column20: The search service at http://www.moic.gov.bh/En/Main/eServices/Commercial%20Registration%20Inquiry/Pages/Commercial%20Registration%20Inquiry.aspx?eserviceID=3 would count as being available online in some form.
column23:
As explained above, there is just a short list for "Latest Company Registration" otherwise one has to search for the company with its Company Registration (CR) number. If the latter is unknown, the search function is basically useless.

The data does not seem available through the Open Data portal (http://bahrain.knoema.com/).

column15: There does not seem to be a centralised place where information is stored. Every Ministry can publish laws relevant for its own functioning. Texts are in these cases in PDF formats and property of the respective Ministry, that is data is non-open.
column18:
Ex. for the TRA: http://www.tra.org.bh/en/legal-instruments/position-papers-and-guidelines/
accessed 23 July 2014.

column15: The Ministry of Transportation provides bus timetables and routes. Pricing is available as well. This information is available both in Arabic and English. Given the size of Bahrain, no trains exist. The website and the data it contains are the Ministry's property, thus data is considered non-open.
column18: No timetable was identified for the 15 bus lines in Bahrain. The routes and fares however are very clearly indicated.
column19:
http://mot.gov.bh/en
http://www.bahrain.bh/wps/portal/MOTBusSchedule (unavailable at the time of the survey, July 23, 2014)
http://mot.gov.bh/en/land-transport/public-transport/public-buses Pricing for public buses
accessed 23 July 2014.
column23: The information available is on the website of the Ministry of Transport or one can get details in a PDF file.

column15:
The Central Bank of Bahrain Statistical Bulletin presents detailed data on monetary and financial indicators, foreign trade and the balance of payments. The Bank's website says the bulletin is published every month, yet the latest issue is from July 2014.

The e-gov portal has a broad yet quite comprehensive overview of the different stakeholders involved in investment and international trade in Bahrain. I have checked them all and listed some of the most important below. None contains details of the import/export of specific commodities.

The US Dept of State publishes a regular review of the investment climate in Bahrain. The latest edition, covering half of the examination period, is linked to below. Since this information exists, it means that there is data collected on the topic. Hence the "data collected but not shared" grade.
column18:

Central Bank of Bahrain Statistical Bulletin for April 2014 http://www.cbb.gov.bh/assets/MSB/MSB-APR2014.pdf
Bahrain International Investment Park http://www.biip.com.bh/
Companies Operational at BIIP http://www.biip.com.bh/default.asp?action=article&id=27
column23: Where information is available, it is generally in PDFs. Sometimes, one finds import-export information (as .xls) but the data is out-dated (from 2009); the latter can be found here: http://www.data.gov.bh/wps/PA_OpenData/DownloadDocument?documentId=163

column15:
The Ministry of Health (MoH) is responsible for collecting this data. On its website, the MoH provides different documents but they do not seem to contain health sector performance data. Instead, one would need to dig into each of them and come up with some sort of meta-indicator. Documents are slightly out-dated (the most recent is for 2012) and in PDF format.
Lastly, the country's e-gov portal has very broad overview.
column18:
http://www.moh.gov.bh/EN/aboutMOH/MOHstatistics.aspx
http://www.moh.gov.bh/PDF/Publications/statistics/HS2012/hs2012_e.htm - statistices by the MoH for 2012

column19:
http://www.moh.gov.bh/EN/aboutMOH/MOHstatistics.aspx

column20: Does not seem so. The Open Data portal does not provide any such data and the five datasets it seems to contain are all more than outdated (http://bahrain.knoema.com/data#topic=Health).
column24: Documents on the MoH website are slightly out-dated (the most recent is for 2012) and in PDF format. The country's Open Data portal on Knoema has summary statistics in machine-readable formats (example: http://bahrain.knoema.com/qdhjiib/bahrain-regional-statistics-2013) yet these are outdated. Thus for instance, the health indicators in the 'Bahrain Regional Statistics 2013' cover the period 2010-2011.
column26: Data can only be downloaded from the Knoema platform following log-in. The data available is only accessible in response to a query interface.
column29: The data is the intellectual property of the MoH.
column34: The files seem to be just uploaded without no clear guidance on the place and the type of information to release. They are also outdated while they should be updated on a regular basis.
column35: One has to dig in different websites and read very general information before getting to some sort of data (summary statistics not on the topic addressed in this survey).

column15:
The Ministry of Education and the Supreme Council for Education should have this data. No such data was, however, identified; the researcher's requests to World Bank MENA, Unicef and Unesco did not identify any data either.

The Ministry of Education has a page where it is supposed to publish Higher-Ed Statistics. The page is empty.

The country's Open Data portal on Knoema publishes summary statistics (http://bahrain.knoema.com/qdhjiib/bahrain-regional-statistics-2013) but these are outdated (only cover 2010). Also, in order to download the data, one has to log in.

column20: No up to date data was available.

column26: The data does not seem to be published online in any form whatsoever. Only outdated data is available (for 2010, in .xls or .csv) through Bahrain's Knoema portal: http://bahrain.knoema.com/qdhjiib/bahrain-regional-statistics-2013 To download anything, one has to log in on Knoema.
column27: Data can be freely downloaded from the Knoema portal.

column15:
Given that the OSAC has published an extensive report on crime in Bahrain, I assume data exists. It is however not shared. The Ministry of Interior is responsible for this data.

The only thing which might seem like crime-related numbers is available on the so called Open Data portal. These numbers are more justice-related though (number of cases judged in cassation courts, based on shari'a law, etc.) than actual crime statistics.

column15: Bahrain solely holds elections for the Chamber of Deputies (lower Chamber of the bicameral Bahraini Parliament, the Shura Council members being appointed by the King). The website http://www.vote.bh/ was supposed to link to candidates and results from the latest elections in Bahrain (2010) but the website does not seem to operate anymore.

column15:
"The Tender Board is a fully independent body, established by a Royal Decree on 7 January 2003". The US Dept of State Investment Climate Statement for Bahrain complements: "In October 2002, Bahrain implemented a new government procurement law that establishes the basic framework for a transparent, rules-based government procurement system. It provides that certain procurements may be conducted as international public tenders open to foreign suppliers. To implement this law, a tender board chaired by a Minister of State was established in January 2003 to oversee all government tenders and purchases."
(http://www.state.gov/e/eb/rls/othr/ics/2012/191105.htm)

The Tender Board has a list of opened, to be opened, closed and awarded tenders. The data is not published according to the terms of the Open Definition though. I have also chosen to select "data collected but not shared" as the information available is very limited (name of company and amount of tender funding) and not always up-to-date (for ex., the latest listing of awarded tenders is from June 2014).

column15:
Quite a bit of performance data is available on primary and secondary education. While the national level secondary examinations results are published, it is not done at the same level for primary education. Following are the agencies responsible for this data: 

(1) Directorate of Primary Education, Ministry of Primary and Mass Education
(2) Directorate of Secondary and Higher Education, Ministry of Education

column15: Detailed crime data are not shared as open data. All other regional/divisional police headquarters also provide statistics at varied levels.

column15:
The Belgian National Geographic Institute (Institut Géographique National - Belgique, IGN) is responsible for the map data at national level in the country (1).

##Sources
(1) Institut Géographique National, http://www.ngi.be/FR/FR0.shtm Accessed on 2014-08-15
column18:
The Belgian mapping agency provides digital map data in vector format in different scales (1:10000, 1:50000, 1:250000). Respective products are known as Top10Vector, Top50Vector and Top250Vector (1). Data includes roads, railways and other important infrastructures. Administrative boundaries are available in another product named AdminVector and available in 1:10000 scale (2).

##Sources
(1) http://www.ngi.be/FR/FR1-5-1.shtm Accessed on 2014-08-15
(2) http://www.ngi.be/FR/FR1-5-2.shtm Accessed on 2014-08-15
column20:
Yes, Open Street Map provides an high density digital map of the country in ODbL license that can be used as a background map (1). Map includes administrative boundaries (2).

##Sources
(1) http://www.openstreetmap.org/#map=8/50.627/4.227 Accessed on 2014-08-15
(2) http://tools.geofabrik.de/osmi/?view=boundaries&lon=4.33893&lat=50.70335&zoom=8 Accessed on 2014-08-15

column15:
The service in charge of land ownership data is the General Administration of Patrimonial Documentation (Documentation Patrimoniale) placed under the Federal Public Service for Finance (Service Public Fédéral Finances, SPF Finances) formerly the Ministry of Finance (1).

##Sources
(1)Documentation Patrimoniale, SPF Finance, http://finances.belgium.be/fr/sur_le_spf/structure_et_services/administrations_generales/documentation_patrimoniale/ Accessed on 2014-08-18
column18: Data can be accessed and copied online by federal agents, real estate agents or citizen with an electronic id card.
column19:
An digital extract of the cadastre can be requested from the official cadastral map viewer, http://ccff02.minfin.fgov.be/cadgisweb/?local=fr_BE Accessed on 2014-08-18

People can also access extract of their own property here https://eservices.minfin.fgov.be/portal/fr/public/citizen/patrimoine/realgoods Accessed on August 18, 2014

Real estate agents can also access cadastral information from the Cadastre Finder, http://ipi.cadastrefinder.be/Account/LogOn?ReturnUrl=%2f Accessed on 2014-08-18
column23: No extract available online. It is possible to get a csv file for free from the map viewer with information on selected parcels: ID number, type and surface. However, alone, these information are not sufficient to be considered as a land ownership dataset. Format gml, shp, csv

column15: Statistics Belgium (Direction générale Statistique et Information économique, DGSIE, ex-INS) is part of the Federal Public Service Economy.
column18: The statistics agency provides information on population, work, economy, environment and energy on its portal called statbel.
column20: Some data from statbel can also be found on the federal open data portal run by Fedict (Federal Public Service for ICT). You can also find regional statistics data on local open data portal http://opendata.awt.be/dataset/population-par-communes-2013
column24: Data are stored in xls files in a non-structured model. You may need additional processing.
column29:
No evidence of an open data license nor on statbel website neither on the federal open data portal. Terms of use of the open data portal state that the data can only be reused for personal purposes(1), which is against open data principles.

##Sources
(1) data.gov.be, conditions d'utilisation, http://data.gov.be/fr/conditions-dutilisation Accessed on 2014-08-19
column34:
The country has a long record of statistics data collection and publication (1).

##Sources
(1) http://statbel.fgov.be/en/statistics/organisation/statistics_belgium/history/ Accessed on 2014--8-19
column35:
A search engine request with "statistique belgique" as keywords will led you to the main webpage of the statistics data portal http://statbel.fgov.be/fr/statistiques/chiffres/
From here you will easily find the information on the dataset.

column26: There are two dataset, one for revenues, the other for expenditures, both covers the whole budget.
column27: There is no evidence for a charging policy.
column29: There is no mention of a license for the data. However there is a global copyright for the website.
column33: Yearly (only 2014 budget is made available online though, not the previous ones)
column34:
The Budget Online webpage states that only information from most recent budgets are made available. Therefore the publication can be considered as sustainable but not the archiving (1).

column35: A search engine request with "budget belgique publication" as keywords will led you to the main webpage of the Budget Online webpage http://www.begroting.be/FR/pages/budgetOnline.aspx From here you will easily find the information on the dataset.

column15:
The General Administration of the Treasury (Administration générale de la Trésorerie) from the Federal Public Service Finance (Service Public Fédéral Finance, SPF Finance) (1) is responsible for the federal accounting system.

##Sources
(1) http://finances.belgium.be/fr/Contact/info_tresorerie/ Accessed on 2014-08-19
column18:
The country has a central Public Finance Management Information System (PFMIS) called FEDCOM which is also used for Waloon and Brussels governments (1). Transnational level spending data should be managed and stored on that system. 

##Sources
(1) Ernst & Young, Bookkeeping systems used by public entities in Overview and comparison of public accounting and auditing practices in the 27 EU Member States, p 38,  http://epp.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/portal/page/portal/government_finance_statistics/documents/study_on_public_accounting_and_auditing_2012.pdf Accessed on 2014-08-19

column15:
The Belgian Business Register (Banque-Carrefour des Entreprises, BCE) of the Federal Public Service of Economy (Service Public Fédéral Écomomie, SPF Économie) (1).

##Sources
(1) SPF Économie - BCE - Open Data, http://economie.fgov.be/fr/entreprises/bce/pub/opendata/ Accessed on 2014-08-18
column18: The open dataset contains information on both companies and their establishments.
column24: the company dataset comes in 8 csv files included in a zip file
column26: The company dataset comes in 8 csv files (company, establishment, address, contact, code, activity, denomination)  each one covers all the country.
column27: basic data is available for free, while a more detailed dataset can be obtained against a license fee
column29: The data are published under a dedicated license entitled "Licence Open Data". This license grants the license holder the right to share, modify and use the data. However some conditions restrict the use of the data. For instance Article 2.1 states that: "The license holder can not reuse the data for a distinct purpose from the one mentioned when registering to download the files". This is not compliant with an Open Data licence.
column34: Publication of company data is quite new (May 2014) but the Belgian Government, via the SPF Économie, made a strong commitment
column35: All information are available on the company registry website.

column15:
At federal level, the Moniteur Belge, from the Federal Public Service Justice (Service Public Fédéral Justice, SPF Justice), is responsible for the data (1). Legislation data from federal and regional levels can also be found on the Central Legislation Databank (2).

##Sources
(1) Moniteur Belge, http://justice.belgium.be/fr/service_public_federal_justice/organisation/moniteur_belge/ Accessed on 2014-08-18
(2) Central Legislation Databank, http://www.belgiumlex.be/en/index.html Accessed on August 2014-08-19
column18: All legislation data (laws, decrees, etc.) are made available on a legislation data portal and can be browsed by date of publication, type, keywords, etc.
column20:
Up-to-date legislation data can also be found on a website called Etaamb which is a personal project considered as a prototype (1). However there is no mention of the license of the data on the website.

##Sources
(1) Etaamb, http://www.etaamb.be/fr/index.html Accessed on 2014-08-19
column23: Only available in PDF or html format.

column15:
NMBS/SNCB is the National rail company(1); The main regional transport services companies are: De Lijn (busses, trams and subway in Flanders), TEC (busses, trams and subway in Wallonia), The STIB/MIVB (busses, trams and subway in Brussels).

(4) STIB/MIVB, http://www.stib-mivb.be/index.htm?l=fr Accessed on 2014-08-20
column18:
Most of the companies provide timetable and real time information on their website. For the rest of the survey we will only assess national rail company NMBS/SNCB. However we should note here that TEC is now publishing some its data in CC-BY (1), as well as STIB/MIVB (2) though the licence is not open data.

column15:

column15:
Each regional government is responsible for the education system in its territory, and as such for the collection and publication of the data. column16: No datasets exist, neither for the capital city. No details of when and where public transport services such as buses and rail services are expected to run exist nor a national dataset even for the key cities of Cotonou and Porto-Novo. There a no such organized public transport providers in the Country nor formal public transport lines operated by the government. Only GSM operators provide planes schedules via some added value services.
column17: NO. there is no evidence that government is requiring third-party sharing of this kind of data. The numerous private companies of public transport do not provide this kind of data online. People have to go to the companies' offices to have a clear idea of schedules, departures and arrivals and conditions for carrying goods or persons.

column18:
The Ministry of Health through its Direction de la programmation et de la Prospective (1) provides Statistics generated from administrative data which deal with regional health sector performances and deal with many aspects and indicators such as human resources,  social workers, predominent diseases, etc… 

There is also the national FBR website of the Ministry (2) funded by the World bank that provide performance information per region, health center, and per dimension or services of health such as finance, surgery, etc. However only 6 out of 12 regions are currently covered but the project is still in its implementation phase.

##Sources
(1)Ministère de la santé, Annuaire des statistiques sanitaires 2013 , April 2014,http://www.beninsante.bj/documents/DDS_BA/NKP/ANNUAIRE_STATISTIQUES_2013_ZS-NKP-1.pdf, Accessed on 2014-09-29
(2) Portail Financement Basés sur les Résultats FBR, Ministère de la Santé du Bénin, realtime health sector performances, http://www.beninfbr.org/data.html Accessed on 2014-09-29

column15: The Autonomous Electoral National Commission CENA
column16: The Autonomous Electoral National Commission CENA, is the board that organizes national elections, centralizes and publishes elections results on its web site and then transfer them to the Constitutional Court which is the only one to validate the results. A new CENA is always installed in the event of an electional to national assembly or municipalities. So results data are just available when there is an election. The results data are not held by the government, there are shared but not as open data. There is no data for the study period.
column17: The Autonomous Electoral National Commission CENA is mandated by the law to share the results data with the press, government, the Constitutional court and other third parties like political parties or groups of political parties.However the dedicated website to national elections Beninelections.com provided regular details elections results during the last presidential and legislatives elections.

column15: Ministry of Lands and Housing through The Department of Surveys and Mapping (DSM)
column18:
Data is not available online. However, The Department of Surveys and Mapping is the main national mapping organization of the country.  The major function of the Department is the collection, management and dissemination of geo-spatial data using technologies such as: surveying, mapping, remote sensing and geographic information system.  Besides, being a specialized organization, it provides professional services and advice to Government, parastatals and the private sector on all matters related to above technologies and efficient use of geo-spatial data.

The Mapping Division is responsible for National Mapping Programme using modern technology.  Production is carried out in-house and through contract services.  It provides topographic maps at small, medium and large scales in analogue as well as digital format and special services such as thematic maps (tourist maps, city/town plans, election maps etc.), aerial photographs and remote sensing data.  The Division has acquired a number of advanced Photogrammetric and Cartographic systems to augment the production flow in mapping.  It is also responsible for the Geographic Place Names Act.

column15:
Ministry of Lands and Housing through the department of deeds registry. 

The Deeds Registry takes charge and preserves records registered in the Deeds Registry. Its main function is to register title to surveyed or demarcated pieces of land, owned by the state, individuals and other entities capable of owning land or real rights in land. The division therefore plays a central role in the land registration system of the country and is thus the main source of information regarding land ownership and other real rights attaching to it - http://www.mlh.gov.bw/index.php?option=com_departments&id=29
column18: Data is not available online. This makes it difficult to tell the details of information on land ownership data sets

column15:
The Burkinabè STMB and TCV companies operate transport bus nationwide and connect to other countries. There are other foreign buses companies operating in the country such as STC from Ghana or SNTV from Niger (1). SOTRACO operates  transport bus in the capital Ouagadougou. There is a train line between Ouadougou and Adbidjan (Ivory-Coast) operated by SITARAIL (Bolloré Group). 

(1) Lonely Planet, Burkina Faso, Getting there, http://www.lonelyplanet.com/burkina-faso/transport/getting-there-away Accessed on 2014-08-26
(2) Sotraco, http://sotraco-bf.net/ On maintenance at the date of 2014-08-26
(3) Sitarail on Wikipedia, http://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sitarail Accessed on 2014-08-26
(4) http://tcv-bus.com/destinations.htm Accessed on 2014-08-26
column18:
The existence of these transport companies may imply the existence of transport data but there wer not easy to find online. Only TCV provides with a working website including timetables (1).

##Sources
(1) http://tcv-bus.com/destinations.htm Accessed on 2014-08-26

column18: The Institute provides statistics data on a wide range of sectors as html pages or reports but statistics are often sparse or outdated. The Institute publishes a Statistics Year Book annually but most of the figures on population do not seem regular or periodical but based on one-shot surveys such as the last census of the population that dates back to 2005. The situations with economics statistics seem better though, with regular reports of public finance.
column20:
Some aggregated statistics data from the country are available on the African Development Bank's Open Data portal (1). There is also another platform only dedicated for Cameroon's statistics and supported by the AfDB but this one is very poor in data (2).

##Sources
(1) African Data Portal http://dataportal.afdb.org/  Accessed on 2014-07-03
(2) Cameroon Data Portal http://cameroon.africadata.org/ Accessed on 2014-07-03

column15:
The Chamber for commerce, industry, mining and craft (CCIMA) is responsible for the collection and diffusion of information on companies in Cameroon (1). The eRegulation service maintained by the Ministry of SMEs, Solidarity Economy and Crafts (MINPMEESA) offers information for registration for specific councils but there is no centralized process yet (2). A project on the creation of a central database was mentioned in a 2009 report but there is no evidence such an exhaustive register is operational (3). Finally, the Statistics Institute conducted a Census of Companies in 2009 but it does not provide the list of the companies, the results provided are only about statistics on these companies (4).

(1) CCIMA, http://www.ccima.net/present_fr.php Accessed on 2014-07-03
(2) Cameroon eRegulations, http://cameroun.eregulations.org/ Accessed on 2014-07-03
(3) Observatoire Economique et Statistique d’Afrique Subsaharienne, Atelier sur le traitement des statistiques d’entreprises, February 2009, http://www.afristat.org/contenu/doc_travail_experts/Com_Repertoire-Final_publication.pdf Accessed on 2014-07-03
(4) INS Cameroun, Recensement Général des Entreprises (RGE2009),http://www.statistics-cameroon.org/news.php?id=78 Accessed on 2014-09-09
column16:
There are some lists of companies that are shared but these lists are not complete at all. The Chamber for commerce, industry, mining and craft (CCIMA) maintains a database on industrial companies in the country. The database only have 63 companies registered though. It is possible to export the data in Excel file (1). The CCIMA also provides another listing on its website (1) but there are less than 400 companies available and there is no possibility to export the data easily.

##Sources
(1) Base de données sur les entreprises industrielles du Cameroun (CCIMA), http://www.pointsbiz.com/projets/ccima4/entrepriselist.php Accessed on July 3rd, 2014
(2) CCIMA, Annuaire des entreprises du Cameroun, http://www.ccima.net/annuaire_fr.php Accessed on July 3rd, 2014

column18:
GeoGratis, the portal of the Canada Map Office, offers a wide range of maps including CanVec, a vector format topographic map covering the entire Canadian landmass at a scale of 1:50000 (1). It also provides with an API for developers to access the data. CanVec is tiled based map.

There is a Pan-Canadian Education Indicators Program (PCEIP) draws from a wide variety of data sources to provide information on the school-age population, elementary, secondary and post secondary education. Data is provided at the level of Regions and Provinces, not schools. The Pan-Canadian Education Indicators Program (PCEIP) is an ongoing initiative of the Canadian Education Statistics Council, a partnership between Statistics Canada and the Council of Ministers of Education, Canada that provides a set of statistical measures on education systems in Canada (1).

column15:
There are several websites and agencias in charge of map data. Maybe the most traditional one is the Geographic Military Institute (1), in charge of cartographic information. It is important to note that most of the maps created by IGM are sold and not open. IDE (Infraestructura de Datos Espaciales, Spatial Data Infrastructure is an agency dependent of the Ministry of National Goods focused on managing geospatial data. They provide geographical information via GIS systems (3). It is not clear the relation between IDE and IGM. Finally, some geographic data (e.g., latitude/longitude of schools) is available at the Chilean Data Portal (4).

##Sources

(1): http://www.igm.cl/
(2): http://www.ide.cl
(3): http://geonodo.gorebiobio.cl/index.php/
(4): http://datos.gob.cl/
column19:
For free data by the Geographic Military Institute, http://www.igm.cl/descargas_gratuitas.php
For paid data by the Geographic Military Institute, http://www.igm.cl/#
Several government organizations provides their own IDE portal with their own GIS systems. A list of all of them can be found at http://www.ide.cl/vinculos/sitios-e-ides-de-chile.html
For additional government's data set on the matter, http://datos.gob.cl/categorias/ver/9
column20:
No, the Geographic Military Institute's data is its own data.
Data from datos.gob.cl is available as Open Data.
Data from IDEs are available only via GIS systems
column21: The government data portal provides some data in machine readable format at http://datos.gob.cl/categorias/ver/9.
column24: Not all the data is available in machine readable format. As mentioned early, IGM seldom provides free data, mostly as images. Same with IDEs, who use GIS systems in most cases. Only datos.gob.cl provides certain datasets as Excel of CSV files
column27: Some of the data is available free fd charge but the most interesting (in terms of details) comes from IGM, which sells this data.

There is no direct link. Visit http://www.igm.cl/#, open menu "Venta de Productos IGM" and click on option "Vertices Geodésicos"

column15:
In Chile, land data is registered in a local agency related to each city or municipality. Most of them do not provides data available on the Web. Those that have incorporated more intense use of technology merely allow for making online requests for copies of documents (2).

A secondary source of land ownership data is the tax administration, but, leaving aside its lack of accuracy, that data is used for internal purposes of the tax administration, thus is, for collecting tax related to tenancy of real states (3).

##Sources

(1): http://www.conservadores.cl/paginas/asp/nomina.asp
(2): See e.g. Registrar of Real State of Santiago at http://www.chileatiende.cl/fichas/ver/436
(3): http://home.sii.cl/

The National Institute of Statistics has released the 2002 census data (1). In 2012, a new census took place. However, because of serious technical deficiencies on the census itself, including the omission of a significant amount of the population, in March 2014, data related to that census has became inaccesible (2). The new government that took office in March 2014 has announced the elaboration of a new census in 2017 (3).

Other statistics are collected regularly, including inflation, unemployment, etc. In 2013, some people criticized the CASEN household survey (4), accusing the government of manipulating and misinterpreting the data.

##Sources 

(1): http://datos.gob.cl/datasets/ver/4117
(2): http://www.censo.cl/
(3): http://cnnchile.com/noticia/2014/06/09/anuncian-nuevo-censo-que-se-realizara-en-abril-de-2017
(4): http://www.economist.com/node/21563736
column18: As mentioned above, only the census data from 2002 is available. The 2012 census data is not available anymore.
column19: The 2002 census data is available at http://datos.gob.cl/datasets/ver/4117. Due to the problems related to the 2012 census, the data is not avilable. The CASEN 2011 household survey  is available at http://datos.gob.cl/datasets/ver/1677

column34: This data is critical for lots of public policies. Hence, having up-to-date data is of high priority for the Chilean government.

column15: For creating a companies, contracting parties must sign a contract before a notary, register the information before a registrar, and publish a brief of the contract into the official gazette. Ultimately, for becoming operative, a company must get a national ID number before the tax administration.
column19:
The official gazette offers a limited search mechanism (1) where it is possible to obtain an extract of the contract that creates the company. This search is limited, since the user must know the day, month and year when the company was published, as well as the type of the company.

column23: For each company there is a PDF document which is an extract of the contract.

column15:
The Environment Ministry processes national environmental statistics data on carbon emissions, levels of pollution, and deforestation, among others. However, data is not share as open data. Part of the data has been released through studies, among which it must be highlighted a 2011 Government Report on Environment (1), a bilingual report that includes statistics on different kind of pollution, as well as biodiversity. But data is shown in a pdf format. Other data could be retrieve through individual queries, such as that related to carbon emissions in the capital city (2).  

##Sources

(1): http://www.mma.gob.cl/1304/w3-article-52016.html
(2): http://registro-nh3.mma.gob.cl/paginas/index.php
column19: As aforementioned, the Environment Ministry does not provide open data, but you can find information about its studies and statistics at http://www.mma.gob.cl/1304/w3-propertyvalue-16235.html. Also, some data related to air quality is available via webapps such as http://www.mma.gob.cl/1304/w3-propertyvalue-16214.html

column15:
The Ministry of Land and Resources of the People's Republic of China is responsible for collecting and managing property registration (1).

#Sources
(1) http://www.mlr.gov.cn Accessed on 2014-10-16
column18:
Data is collected but is not online. More precisely, the Ministry of Land and Resources recently announced that a nationwide property registry, as well as the platform for information management, will be operational before 2018 (1) and officially built the Department of Homeland Real Estate Registration Office on May 8, 2014 (2). The registration data was previously collected by various ministries and will be unified under the new registry (2). Previous registration data is also incomplete often. For example, property developers complained about incomplete information about land zoning, saying some local authorities had sold massive amounts of land without considering a possible oversupply of housing and commercial development (1).

Sources: 
(1) Esther Fung, China gives timetable for national property registry, The Wall Street Journal, April 21 2014, http://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052702304049904579515171780345790. Accessed June 10 2014

(2) 中华人民共和国国土资源部，《国土部不动产登记局正式挂牌》, May 09 2014. http://www.mlr.gov.cn/xwdt/mtsy/xinhuanet/201405/t20140509_1316433.htm. Accessed June 10 2014

Data regarding city bus service, inter-city service, and subway service can be found in the passenger service information on the website of Ministry of Transport (1). It is organised based on each first-level administrative division. Data regarding these public transport timetables can be obtained by searching specific route but not available in bulk. 

Data regarding inter-city rail services can be found on the website of railway passenger service centre of the China Railway Bureau under the Ministry of Transport (2). Data regarding these public transport timetables can be obtained by searching specific route but not available in bulk.

column18:
Details of the import and export of specific commodities and balance of trade data against other countries can be found on the Customs Main Statistics webpage (1). The data is displayed as lists of import and export by commodity and country in tables on its webpages. Data format is HTML. The data is not open licensed; 

China Statistic Yearbook database listing yearly international trade data from 1996 (note: 1995 statistics) to 2013 (note: 2012 statistics) (2). Data can be downloaded as Excel spreadsheet but not open licensed ;

Monthly and yearly international trade data can also be obtained on the national data portal (3). Data can be downloaded as machine-readable spreadsheet (excel, CSV, etc.) but not open licensed.

##Sources
(1) http://www.customs.gov.cn/publish/portal0/tab49667 Accessed on 2014-10-16
(2) http://www.stats.gov.cn/tjsj/ndsj/ Accessed on 2014-10-16
(3) http://data.stats.gov.cn/workspace/index?m=hgyd Accessed on 2014-10-16
column23: html only

column15:
The National Health and Family Planning Commission of the People's Republic of China is responsible for the data (1).

##Sources
(1) http://www.nhfpc.gov.cn Accessed on 2014-10-16
column18:
Monthly, quarterly, and yearly health data indicators are released on the website of the National Health and Family Planning Commission (1), including number of health institutions, health service cost, number of patients, etc. The data is displayed in a combination of text and tables on its webpages. Data format is HTML. The data is not open licensed. However there is no data on the health system performance.

China Statistic Yearbook database listing yearly national health indicators from 1996 (note: 1995 statistics) to 2013 (note: 2012 statistics). Data can be downloaded as an Excel spreadsheet but it is not open licensed: 

Yearly health performance data can also be obtained on the national data portal (3) including health system performance but only at national and regional levels. Data includes numbers of medical and health institutions, health personnel, beds in health institutions per 10,000 ppl, incidents of infectious diseases and mortality, total expenditure, etc. Data can be downloaded as machine-readable spreadsheet (excel, CSV, etc.) but not open licensed.

(1) http://www.moh.gov.cn/zwgkzt/pwstj/list.shtml Accessed on 2014-10-16
(2) http://www.stats.gov.cn/tjsj/ndsj/ Accessed on 2014-10-16
(3) http://data.stats.gov.cn/workspace/index?m=hgnd Accessed on 2014-10-16

column18: Data includes number of students and teachers, student: teacher ratio, rates of school attendance and teacher attendance. No data of test scores for pupils in national examinations is found. Data is in HTML format and not under open license;
column19:
Primary and secondary education performance data can be obtained from the data index published on the website of the Ministry of Education (1). Data includes number of students and teachers, student: teacher ratio, rates of school attendance and teacher attendance. No data of test scores for pupils in national examinations is found. Data is in HTML format and not under open license; 

Yearly primary and secondary education data can also be obtained on the national data portal (2). Data can be downloaded as machine-readable spreadsheet (excel, CSV, etc.) but are not open data.

column18:
Elections in the People's Republic of China are based on a hierarchical electoral system, whereby local People's Congresses are directly elected, and all higher levels of People's Congresses up to the National People's Congress, the national legislature, are indirectly elected by the People's Congress of the level immediately below (1). Elections results are provided online by the Central Election Commission (2).

##Sources
(1) http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elections_in_the_People's_Republic_of_China Accessed on 2014-10-16

column15:
There are several maps from Costa Rica available (1) in the web including whole the national territory, but none of them is shared as open data. Most are just images, others are files to be downloaded as PDF and just one option is a file like Google maps interface. Almost all are private sector initiatives and just one is public, from the National University, called Mapoteca (2). Some maps are available from GIS systems from SINAC (Sistema nacional de Area de Conservacion) (3) (4) (5)

(1): http://www.tramitesconstruccion.go.cr/mapas-oficiales.html

The National Registration Agency (1). It is possible to do request related to data, but users must be registered. Not clear if it is possible via phone or mail
(1): http://www.registronacional.go.cr/

The Statistical and Census National Institute (1) portal and the Central Bank(2) website have a lot of national statistical information, in regards to social, employment, economic, environmental, demographic and commerce information. Part of it is updated on a semiannual basis, and another part on a yearly basis. All the information is shared, however it is not shared on a open data format, but in excel files.

(1): http://www.inec.go.cr/
(2): http://www.bccr.fi.cr/

column16:
There is not even a public transportation time set, with really few exceptions, some transport lines such as La Periferica has a time table shared thru the internet, but that's almost the only case. The rest of the cases don't even have the data, since they don't follow any specific schedule, just provide the service as they can. That's the case for the main cities.

The interstate/ provincial transportation do have schedules to be shared, but is a very limited number of cases when the data is available. However, the Public Service Regulator Authority (1) provides some bus route information in jpg (2)

column15: The Ministry of Housing (http://mbbl.dk/english), Urban and Rural Affairs was established after the last parliamentary elections in October 2011. The ministry is responsible for housing, including the real property data administration, urban development in both larger and smaller cities and of development in sparsely populated rural areas. The ministry is a part of the Danish "Basic data program". A part of this program is to coordinate between different registers that have used different definitions of the ownership term, based on the different needs of different registers/institutions. These different definitions will be consolidated into a general concept of real immovable property. The plan is to start distributing this coherent data through a new platform in 2015 where it will be free of use, with open licenses and available in bulk. See http://grunddata-ejendom-adresse.dk/delaftale1
column18:

For private professional use, the data is available through the OIS server but there you have to pay marginal cost (to the distributor) while the data itself is free

column15:
The Danish Competition and Consumer Authority
http://en.kfst.dk/

According to Danish law, all public procurement shall be announced on udbud.dk. Denmark has enacted EU directives on public contracts:
http://europa.eu/youreurope/business/public-tenders/rules-procedures/index_en.htm#denmark_en_benefiting-from-public-contracts

I cannot find any data on the results, who gets the contract, even it is supposed to be open.

Recently, the complaint office decided, that all information regarding public tenders should be open, including names of bidders and prices offered. This has caused a range of objections, specially from the IT industry:
http://www.maqs.com/da/news/2014/01/27/tilbudte-priser-i-offentlige-udbud-er-ikke-langere-hemmelige
column18: This platform concentrates all Danish public procurement data in a single place. It includes compulsorily at least all public works contracts whose value exceeds 500,000 kr., but is less than the current threshold values ​​in the Procurement Directive. It does not include contract awards.

column15: The Egyptian Survey Authority (ESA, officially Public surveying authority) seems to be responsible for this data. It has various departments tasked with topographic maps, geodesy and the likes.

The country maps exist but they are not in digital form. In order to obtain them, one needs to fill a request to the Egyptian Survey Authority (1).

(1) Egyptian survey authority. digital maps. http://www.esa.gov.eg/SellingMapRoomdigital.aspx accessed on 6 Oct 2014
(In English: http://www.esa.gov.eg/eng/ESA_main_eng.aspx)

column15: A cooperation between the MCIT with the ministry of water resources, justice and the private sector.
column16:
It is still a project in progress established since 2012 by the MCIT in cooperation with the ministry of water resources, justice and the private sector to facilitate the registration of agriculture lands and create an electronic portal for agricultural land registration (1, 2).

##Sources:
(1) MCIT. 2012. The national project of automation of the registration of agricultural lands. http://www.mcit.gov.eg/Upcont/Documents/Land_Registery_Flyer2007781683.pdf. Accessed on 7 June 2014

column15: Central Agency for Public mobilization and statistics (CAPMAS) is the official source for providing, preparing and publishing statistical data, information and reports for all organizations, universities, research centers and international organizations, which help in planning, developing and evaluates, for policy formulation and decision-making. http://www.capmas.gov.eg/?lang=2 (in English; accessed 6 Oct 2014)
column18: Anything from education, gender, census (demography) to foreign trade.
column20:
Open Data for Egypt. http://egypt.opendataforafrica.org/data#region=EG-C (it is unclear what the license is here as the mention on the website says "All rights reserved to the African Bank for Development" yet the Terms and Conditions describe an open licence http://egypt.opendataforafrica.org/legal/termsofuse)
African development Bank Group. http://dataportal.afdb.org/default.aspx (no specific mention on licence here)
column24:
To access the data, one needs to go through a browsable database based on the DevInfo software: http://www.censusinfo.capmas.gov.eg/DivInfo/ and then to export selected tables of data.

For other data, e.g. Foreign Trade, only PDFs are provided (see: http://www.capmas.gov.eg/pages_ar.aspx?pageid=1498) The only machine-readable dataset (it is actually a summary statistic of prices of construction materials) is in .xls format and is outdated (www.capmas.gov.eg/pdf/bld_apr.xls)
column26: No bulk download option seems available through CAPMAS database. PDFs and the only .xls file are available for individual download.
column27: Anyone can see the data and browse it.
column29: The data is copyrighted by CAPMAS.
column30: On the bottom of the website.
column31: 2014 Depends on the data in consideration. The CAPMAS Census database thus says that the data is from 1980. Other, actually news items on the homepage, indicate much more recent updates, e.g. "Labour force size reached 27.6 million individual 1st quarter year 2014." Lastly, CAPMAS has published its "Statistics Year Book" for 2014 (http://www.capmas.gov.eg/pdf/Electronic%20Static%20Book2014//page/English%20Pages/English.htm) in September 2014
column34: The CAPMAS website is much more of a per-dataset sharing rather than a real data platform where changes are tracked and recorded. In its current status, the data is more stored in a repo rather than properly described and maintained (different formats, errors such as "service unavailable" are frequent, no links between datasets, etc.).
column35: If one knows the agency, then browsing its website is straightforward. Links to different statistics are on the homepage. The website is regularly showing "Service unavailable" though which is quite discouraging when trying to make queries.

column15: The Egyptian Ministry of Finances: http://www.mof.gov.eg
column18: Approved budget, Monthly budget performance, General Budget Final Account, different economic indicators
column19: On the Ministry of Finances website: http://www.mof.gov.eg/english/pages/statistics.aspx (see also http://www.mof.gov.eg/English/Papers_and_Studies/Pages/Budget2013-2014.aspx, http://www.mof.gov.eg/MOFGallerySource/English/Monthly-Budget-Performance.pdf and  http://www.mof.gov.eg/MOFGallerySource/Arabic/budget2013-2014/Financial_statement13-14.pdf)
column20: Does not seem so. No such data was identified through the AfDB/World Bank either.
column23: Files are mainly PDFs (or Excel sheets exported as PDF). The few .xls one finds are very outdated and so excluded from this analysis (ex. http://www.mof.gov.eg/MOFGallerySource/English/Reports/links%20for%20all/sept2004/3B-%20BOP.xls)

column15: The Egyptian Ministry of Finances: http://www.mof.gov.eg
column18: Spending data in Egypt is not really available: the Ministry of Finance publishes laws, quaterly briefs and suchlikes, but very few actual data. When the latter is available online, it is through PDFs. The Central Bank of Egypt also publishes data (see here for ex.: http://www.cbe.org.eg/English/Economic+Research/Time+Series/). Here, format is XLS.
column19:
See 'Economic indicators' on the Minitrsy's website. This section has various information, e.g. http://www.mof.gov.eg/English/publications/MOF_Publications/Pages/TheFinancialMonthly-September2014.aspx
The Central Bank of Egypt: http://www.cbe.org.eg/English/Economic+Research/Time+Series/
column23: On the Ministry of Finances website, all documents are PDFs (and rare outdated .xls). Financial information (which is not spending) on the CBE's website is available as .xls

column15: Egyptian International Trade Point. Ministry of Trade and Industry and Investment. http://www.tpegypt.gov.eg/Eng/EgyDirectory.aspx
column18: A list of number of companies per type of activity. When clicking on the activity category, one is sent to a page where names are listed; clicking on each name provides further detail on the company. Unclear how recent the data is though.
column19: Egyptian International Trade Point. Ministry of Trade and Industry and Investment. http://www.tpegypt.gov.eg/Eng/EgyDirectory.aspx
column23: There are no files available for download, it is only static web pages.

column15: The Egyptian Cabinet - State Information Service provides few laws and the latest Constitution on the e-government portal (Arabic and English) http://www.egypt.gov.eg/english/laws/default.aspx
column18: The 2014 Constitution, Law of personal status, Personal Affairs Law, Labour Law, Sales Tax, Environemnt Law, Banking Law, Companies Law, Insurance Law, Law of Investment Guarantees and Incentives, Rules & Procedures of Civil Workers Incentives, Income Tax and a few others. These are available in Arabic only.
column19:
The Egyptian Cabinet - State Information Service provides few laws and the latest Constitution on the e-government portal http://www.egypt.gov.eg/english/laws/default.aspx Laws and constitution are available through pdf and word format, not as open data (xml file)

accessed on 5 June 2014
column20: Some data or information may be available through a third-party website, e.g. Constitutionnet (Constitutional History of Egypt, http://www.constitutionnet.org/country/constitutional-history-egypt). Oftentimes, the Constitution has been translated into English from English-speaking journalists (e.g. these from state-owned news outlet Ahram Online). Yet, in these cases, the translation is generally published on the website and possibly a Word document may be joined, the content remaining copyrighted by the newspaper.
column23: The files are .doc and .pdf, often gathered in a .zip. Looking at ConstitutionNet, e.g. the English translation of the 2014 Constitution (http://www.constitutionnet.org/vl/item/egypt-constitution-2014) shows only PDF is available.

column15: The Ministry of Health is the line ministry with responsibility for health services, however CAPMAS seems responsible for managing data on health services. See the information and the data they provide in their Yearbook (http://www.capmas.gov.eg/pdf/Electronic%20Static%20Book2014//PDF/health/Untitled.pdf for 2014)
column18:
The website of the ministry of health does not provide any statistics on the health sector performance. Data is usually available through international organizations, mainly the WHO. The MCIT provides very few statistics on the medical institutions or staff using ICT in their work (1). Another website affiliated to the ministry of health should provide health statistics but it not working (2).

##Sources:
(1) MCIT. ICT for health. http://www.egyptictindicators.gov.eg/en/Pages/default33.aspx. accessed on 10 June 2014
(2) Ministry of health. the guide for health information and statistics. http://163.121.103.127/Dinfo.aspx. Accessed on 10 June 2014
