column15: The Ministry of State of environmental affairs provides information in html format on the air quality for today and the next 2 days. Nothing more, no historical data and only to one index and that's atmospheric particulate matter (PM10): http://www.eeaa.gov.eg/arabic/main/env_air_aqi.asp Regarding the water resources of the country, annual reports are available on the dedicated page: http://www.eeaa.gov.eg/arabic/main/env_water.asp
column19: Ministry of Environment. This page provides information on the air quality for today and the next two days, for Cairo only. Nothing more, no historical data and only to one index and that's atmospheric particulate matter (PM10). Regarding the water resources of the country, annual reports are available on the dedicated page: http://www.eeaa.gov.eg/arabic/main/env_water.asp
column20: Open Data for Africa http://egypt.opendataforafrica.org/wfhzeob/environment (more on CO2 emissions, not on the information available on the Egyptian Ministry of Environment). Licensing is not clear though as the website has two contradicting terms (one is full copyright, the other is a CC-by-SA-like license)
column23: Air: It is just a static page on the Ministry of Environment website. Water: PDF files only.

column15: The Higher Electoral Commission is responsible for the elections in Egypt: https://www.elections.eg/en/
column18: Elections are available in separate subdomains accessible from a dropdown list on the upper left hand corner of the website. All data is licensed under restrictive terms (data belongs to the Higher Electoral Commission). Presidential elections committee for the presidential elections provides the elections results since the constitutional referendum of March 2011 till the last presidential elections of 2014. Legislative elections are only partly reflected (http://house2013.elections.eg/ocv/ocv-stats, featuring solely Egyptians abroad breakdown).
column21: Example for the presidential elections of 2014: https://pres2014.elections.eg/presidential-elections-2014-results
column24: No metadata seems to be included.
column26: For the latest election a detailed bulk data file is available.
column27: Anyone can access and download the data.
column29: "All rights reserved to the High Elections Committee 2014"
column33: Irregular. Given the lively political scape in Egypt, elections are held quite often, so the website has them as they come. Since the website and the committee behind it take care of the data, at least.
column34: Each dataset is published as is, no link between different ones and no metadata associated.
column35: Once the person lands on the Commission website, each election is clearly indicated on the top (right hand).

column15:
The government procurement portal provides tenders/auctions notices and facilitates the submission process of electronic proposals.

Several ministries have their own portals, providing auctions related to their respective fields: these are the Ministries of Trade, Industry and Investment; Transport; Electricity and renewable energy; Housing, utilities and urban communities; Agriculture; Military production.

column15: Estonian Land Board
column18: Extensive digital maps and map dataset, being the largest state map producer and administrator of spatial data. It is possible to browse backdrop maps and data layers and by combining them to create different thematic maps. The created maps can be shared or printed. User registration provides additional capabilities for adding, managing and sharing your own data layers. In 2008, Web-based map services (WMS) were added to the public map server; the Land Board’s maps can be accessed through these services using various GIS/CAD software.
column19:
Estonian Land Board Geoportal http://geoportaal.maaamet.ee/eng/
INSPIRE maps http://inspire.maaamet.ee/language/1
column28: You can also order data for a fee http://geoportaal.maaamet.ee/eng/Ordering-Data/Ordering-digital-map-datasets-p325.html
column29: No license information and global site copyrigth
column34: Supported by the landing and maps agency
column35: The geoportal is one of the first results in a simple web search and once there it is not difficult to find different maps data

column15: The e-Land Register
column18:
A convenient accessible service which allows quick and easy verification of general data, size, owners, restrictions and encumbering mortgages of immovable properties. 
Accessing the land register as a citizen enables to view the land register documents is free of charge. Authentication of a person via ID card or an Internet bank link is required in order to use the service. Contractual users have access to the e-land register, e-commercial register, the European Business Register and the Visualised Business Register. In order to use the service one has to log in with a user name and a password or with an ID card. It is possible to mandate (share) data viewing rights to other identified parties.
There are XML services: a person’s immovable properties, detailed data about an immovable property, immovable properties in a cadastre unit.
column24: requires registration and aggrement
column26: Unclear as there is no detailed documentation of the web service
column27: Basic information is available for free. Details need payment
column29: No license information and global site copyright
column34: Supported by the official land register
column35: First result for a simple web search

column15: All data of the National Statistics Bureau (http://www.stat.ee/en) is available to the public, published under schedule.
column18: The Bureau is one of the most important generators of open data in Estonia. It is possible to download and share the data in different forms.
column24: Data can be exported in different formats from the online query system

column34: Official census supported by the statistics office

column15: Ministry of Finance and National Statistics Bureau
column18:
The Ministry of Finance provide a site titled Riigiraha (State Finances), which has made public all accounting data retrieved from local governments between 2008 and 2013. The new platform gives the public unlimited access to view, download (in XLS and CSV formats), compare and analyse the data.
http://riigiraha.fin.ee/geoqlik/proxy/QvAJAXZfc/opendoc.htm?document=Riigiraha.qvw&host=local&anonymous=true&select=LB_LANGUAGE,English

However, no equivalent platform for the national government spending could be located, and the following questions assess against the national picture for comparability with other countries.

Centre of Registers and Information Systems http://www.rik.ee/
Registry of Economic Activities http://mtr.mkm.ee
column18: The e-Business Register is a service based on the database of the registry departments of county courts and displaying the real-time data of all legal persons registered in Estonia. Data related to a person can be viewed by logging in with ID-card. Contractual customers get more data and services but have to pay.

column15: Liikennevirasto / Finnish Transport Agency, www.liikennevirasto.fi
column18:
The Finnish Transport Agency (FTA) offers the access right to Matka.fi (Journey.fi) API when the application or service supports public transport usage and public transport information provision. Development and testing as well as commercial use of interfaces is free of charge.
There are two possible ways to access timetable and route data:
HTTP GET interface, which gives a response in XML format
Kalkati.net formatted XML database dump file, which includes the whole Matka.fi stop, route and timetable information in a single file.
column24: HTTP GET interface, which gives a response in XML format
column26: The dump file represents the line and timetable data of the Matka.fi timetable database exported into a single file

column18:
Foreign Trade Statistics
Foreign Trade Statistics describes the commodity trade between Finland and other Member States of the European Union (EU) and between Finland and Third Countries i.e. the internal and external trade. Foreign Trade Statistics is the official information source on the importation, exportation, and balance of trade of Finland.

The goods statistics in Uljas are presented in accordance with
- CN: The Combined Nomenclature, of the EU

- SITC: The Standard International Trade Classification

- CPA: Classification of Products by Activities

- NACE: National industrial classification based on Statistical Classification of Economic Activities in the European Community (Nomenclature générale des Activités économiques dans les Communautés européennes, NACE).

column26: This is an open question: The shapes to the level of municipalities are all available in one big file, with different levels (Federal, states, counties, municipalities), older versions are available on an archive site (http://www.geodatenzentrum.de/auftrag1/archiv/vektor/vg250_ebenen/), which allows choosing the right projection quickly (i.e. for 2009: http://www.geodatenzentrum.de/auftrag1/archiv/vektor/vg250_ebenen/2009/)

column34: The dataset is published on an annual basis and has been provided in an archive form for more than the last 15 years. The data is published by a Federal agency, and is based on a National Regulation which declares all presently known and unknown uses as free.
column35: Open Federal geodata have only been available since March 2013 - however, the site on which they are provided has improved. Now a dedicated point "Open Data" exists in the left navigation. The data can be found rather easily, a search such as "verwaltungsbezirke bund shapefile open data" returns the site in the first results.

column15:
Due to the federal state system, there is no national dataset. Each federal state maintains its own dataset. The data is not publicly available due to revenue and privacy reasons.
In June 2013, the G8 nations published the Open Data Charter, which appears promising for Germany and France in terms of cadastre data. It is supposed to be published within two years (=2015), but until now no publicly noticeable action has taken place. For instance, a national action plan was supposed to be published until the end of 2013, which first happened on 2014-09-17. Also, no German version of the Charter existed until the end of 2013. Partly this can be explained with the delay caused by the national elections in September 2013 and the resulting coalitions negotiations.

The first instance is a dedicated site allowing thorough access to datasets (see answer b) - the license conditions, however, are not completely obvious, as they claim the information my not be altered or forged.

The data also was provided on the German OGD portal govdata.de - this allowed directly downloading csv and xls datasets under clear license conditions. The entries are now missing on the site. In an e-mail (1), a technical professional explained this to me as a harvesting problem - the referred to datasets would no longer exist. However, they do so, which causes some irritation with me.

(1) E-Mail by Benjamin Dittwald, Fraunhofer-Institute for Open Communication Systems, 2014-09-15

column15:
The Federal Ministry of Finances
The budget is a so-called "official work", which is not subject to copyright.
It can be found on the dedicated budget website bundeshaushalt-info.de as well as the OGD portal govdata.de
column20: http://offenerhaushalt.de/haushalt/bund/ (only basically, as the most recent Federal data is from 2012)
column24: The data is available in several file formats (csv, xls, xml) and in two character encodings (utf-8, win-1252) and different separations (comma, semicolon).
column26: The data are available for the years 2012 and 2013 as well on the same site, but only as xls files.
column29: The site does not give any explicitly named license, but states the data may be copied, distributed, processed and mashed-up with other data, also for commercial causes.
column33: Yearly with one or two revisions during the fiscal year, called "Nachtragshaushalt" (amending budget).
column34: The Ministry of Finances chose to publish the data in an open form in 2012 and has continued for the following years. A further publication can be expected, especially when taking into account that the new Federal government included publishing data in an open form in its coalition agreement in fall 2013.
column35: Besides knowing the site from experience, a very simple Google query ("bundeshaushalt offene daten") leads to the site.
column36:

The example provided below consists of the debit side ("soll") and the individual plan for the budget position with the number 600283624. It corresponds with the budget position in the budget plan.

column15:
The Federal Ministry of Finances - the data is only shared in a PDF form, so working with it in terms of open is not possible. (1) Further data is published only on the website, not in a downloadable, reusable form. (2)

column15:
The state is between "Data collected, but not shared" and "Data shared, but not as open data":
Certain basic data can be viewed without costs, other data has to be obtained against a fee of at least 4,5 EUR per document. The documents are obtained by the respective courts where the data is kept. These amounts may be considered as marginal costs, yet the can easily sum up to high costs.

column23: Closed-off version, only via search form.

column15: The Federal Ministry of Justice + Juris GmbH (a federally owned publisher) together publish the laws.
column20: The developer Stefan Wehrmeyer built a version control edition of the federal German laws on http://bundestag.github.io/gesetze/
column24: Each law or administrative order has an individual sub-site, which allows choosing the format (html, pdf, xml, epub) - all except html are followed by a download of the file.
column26: It is not possible to download all laws at once. However one can download each law when clicking onto it as xml.
column29: There is no dedicated license, however, acts, ordinances, official decrees and official notices are not subject to copyright protection in Germany (Article 5, Copyright Act).
column31: Depending on the respective act, the updates are frequently carried out. Consolidation does take some time, however.
column34: As the legislation has been updated and gets updated regularly, there is no reason to doubt future updates.
column35: Short Google query on "Gesetze im Internet" pointed me to the resource.

column15:
The data for the national (and state-owned)train company "Deutsche Bahn" is not shared publicly, yet with map operators such as Google (1). The capital (Berlin) shares its data as one of the very few ones in the entire nation. Data is provided in GTFS format and via an XML API. It is licensed under CC-BY conditions.

(There is not such thing yet like a national bus grid, as the public train system is very well equipped.)

(1) http://www.spiegel.de/netzwelt/web/google-bekommt-fahrplaene-fuer-den-nahverkehr-a-856802.html

Data is collected at the Federal Statistics Office and its state equivalents. Due to each federal state being fully responsible for its educational system, obtaining performance data is quite difficult. No pupil performance data is available, a very general teaching statistic can be found under (1). An overview on schools under (2).
A comprehensive report (3) on the educational system is compiled by the "Deutsches Institut für Internationale Pädagogische Forschung" (German Institute for International Educational Research) - some of the data can be downloaded in an Excel format (4)

column34: Definitely sustainable, publication year by year since 1953, machine-readable data only for 2012 and 2013, PDF versions for the years before that.
column35: Quick Google search on "polizeiliche kriminalstatistik" or "kriminalstatistik" leads to the Federal Criminal Office's proper sites.

column15: The Federal Environment Agency
column18:
The Agency maintains a vast number of datasets, which it has reorganized on its website in a dedicated data sub-site (1). Yet it does not meet the expectations of a repository, because very many entries are just text with a few numbers in it. Still, data for instance on particulate matter (2) in the air can be found there in Excel formats. Other air quality data is only downloadable in CSV format on a daily basis, so downloading values for an entire year would be very difficult (3).

The other site for researching data is Portal U, which is basically a meta site. It bundles all the different data sources all over Germany. This is an advantage and disadvantage at the same time, as on still faces the shortcomings of individual sites. In particular, no verdict can be made on the license, as it differs for each source site (4).
column24: XLSX data includes graphics at top of table, so practical machine-readability is limited.
column26: Even though having a dedicated "data" section, the website is more about exploring and displaying data, less about retrieving data in a structured and efficient way.
column29: Unclear. Possibly, as measurement results data aren't subject to copyright. However, no indicators can be found, neither on sites, in documents or on imprint.
column31: The data is in some cases updated on a daily base, in other cases published for an entire year.
column33: Depending on dataset, up to daily.
column34: As continually monitoring and collecting environmental data is one of the core tasks of the Agency, sustainability definitely applies.
column35: Quick google search on "Umweltdaten Deutschland" gets the user to the site, including the "Data" section.

column15: Bundeswahlleiter (Federal Returning Officer)
column18: The data may be used under an attribution license, alterations to the data must be indicated.
column24: Real machine-readable data, no fuss.
column26: Most of the data is only available in PDF form, a lot is quite difficult to find. In some stages, a sub-site provides numerous csv datasets, in other cases only PDF. No possibility to collect or download everything in a zip.
column29: According to the Govdata portal a free (=unlimited) use is possible. This also has to do with the fact that such results are not subject to copyright in Germany.
column31: Provisional result: 2013-09 - very shortly after Federal election day. Final result: 2014-05-15.
column33: Depending on election day - usually on the same day of election or early the next day. Final result usually several months after election (May 2014 in this case).
column34: The Federal Returning Officer works reliable on publishing the data regularly. Older data are provided, however, the information architecture is improvable at its best. Also, a lot of results are only published in PDF format.
column35: If choosing the Govdata portal, very quickly - if choosing bundeswahlleiter.de, pretty difficult, as going by "Ergebnisse" (results) doesn't provide machine-readable data - that is found under "publications".

column15: Federal Office of Administration (Bundesverwaltungsamt)
column18: The data is collected by the Federal Office of Administration. It includes open tenders and granted tenders - the search is limited to the 500 most recent entries.
column20:
One additional possibility would be to access the data on a European level, using Tenders Electronic Daily in a version scraped by Open Spending (1), and filtering the data by the country Germany. This does not reflect the threshold (2) under which tenders don't have to be published in entire Europe.

(1) http://ted.openspending.org/
(2) http://europa.eu/youreurope/business/public-tenders/tools-database/index_de.htm#germany_de_benefiting-from-public-contracts

column15: Ministry of Lands and Natural Resources specifically Survey and Mapping Division
column18:
The Survey and Mapping Division is responsible for Map data in Ghana. Despite the fact that data is not available online, it is reported that the Division is responsible for mapping and maintain the national territorial boundaries including maritime - http://www.ghanalap.gov.gh/index.php/survey-and-mapping-division#boundaries;


There is quite a lot of data in Ghana shared as open data. For example, the Ghana districts' website provides information on all the regions, including the following:
•	background of the region
•	political administration
•	nationality and ethnicity
•	population characteristics
•	housing characteristics
•	policy implications
•	cultural and social structure
•	economic activity and employment
•	social characteristics
•	community facilities

One can also find a map showing the country by administrative regions. See <http://www.ghanadistricts.com/region/?r=2&sa=8>
column20: Ghanaweb.com also publishes all sorts of information about Ghana in addition to daily news. See <http://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/geography/maps.php>.

column15:
Ministry of Lands and Natural Resources through the Land Registration Division

The Lands Commission is mandated to hold land ownership data but is not required to provide it to the public or as open data. This is why there are often double sales of lands leading to prolonged court cases.
column18: It is reported that one of the Land Registration Division roles is to  Publication of notices of registration upon receipt of an application for registration; Registration of title to land and other interests in land; Registration of deeds and other instruments affecting land in areas outside compulsory title registration districts and Maintaining land registers that contains records of land and other interests in land - http://www.ghanalap.gov.gh/index.php/land-registration-division2
column20: The data is not available as open data from a third party.

column15:
The Ghana Statistical Service is responsible for providing national statistics datasets in the country. See <http://www.statsghana.gov.gh/. The information available at the GSS website includes:
 
•	National Statistics on the economic, social and demographic information
•	Censuses and Surveys
•	Data Request
column18: There is information on Population and Housing census.
column19:
1. The Ghana Statistical Service is responsible for providing national statistics datasets in the country. See http://www.statsghana.gov.gh/.

2. The National Data Archive (NADA): <http://www.statsghana.gov.gh/docfiles/publications/Comp_of_Stats_Stand_Variab_and_Conc_for_Off_Stats_in_Ghana_2013.pdf>

column15: The Ministry of Finance
column18:
The information on budgets includes expenditures allocated to various Ministries and government agencies as well as proposed revenues.
The http://data.gov.gh website hosts a number of finance datasets, although out of the context of the wider budget documents.

column24: The data linked above is an appendix to the 2014 Budget, providing relevant past and projected figures. However, the meta-data around it makes it difficult to read in the context of the overall budget.

column27: The pdf reports can freely be accessed at no cost. As can data on data.gov.gh
column29: No license information is provided at http://data.gov.gh/dataset/2014-budget-appendix-1
column34: The information is sustainable because there is various information on the website.
column35: Basic Information can easily be discovered on the Finance Ministry website where there is a link to budget documentation. Crimes statistics can freely be accessed on the Ghana Open Data Initiative at no cost.

The data is public and free to access as per the policy 

"The National Data Sharing and Accessibility Policy (NDSAP) is the policy which facilitates the access to Government of Ghana owned shareable data and information in both human readable and machine readable forms through Data Portal Ghana in a proactive and periodically updatable manner, within the framework of various related policies, Acts and rules of Government of Ghana, thereby, permitting wider accessibility and use of public data and information.

NDSAP will apply to all the data and information generated, collected and archieved using the public funds provided by Government of Ghana directly, with the help of various Ministries/ Departments/Organisations/ Agencies and Autonomous bodies"

column15:
The Mapping and Cadastral Organization of Greece is responsible, among others, to maintain and update the National Geospatial Information Infrastructure. The NATIONAL CADASTRE & MAPPING AGENCY S.A. company is a Legal Entity of Private Law and its mission is the study, development and operation of the Hellenic Cadastre. The sole shareholder of the company is the Ministry of Environment, Energy and Climate Change. 
http://www.ktimatologio.gr/sites/en/aboutus/Pages/6PwCSkOZyozWeUix_EN.aspx
column18: It is not clear from the website what data is available.
column19:
Online maps from the Hellenic Cadastre http://gis.ktimanet.gr/wms/ktbasemap/default.aspx
Web-based digital maps are also provided for some areas of interest, e.g. contested forests: http://gis.ktimanet.gr/wms/forestobjections/ - However, while the orthophoto surveys are accessible to the public, major features can only be seen in basic summary when a point on the map is clicked - i.e. the borders and roads are not visible on the map.

The government Open Geodata portal provides more detailed maps and data for download: http://geodata.gov.gr/geodata/
column20: OpenStreetMap publishes open maps with decent coverage of Greece and surroundings, where the data is very accessible: http://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/WikiProject_Greece
column24:
Orthophotos of the entire Greek territory with the exception of some border areas and certain classified facilities. The spatial resolution of the images is 20cm to 50cm, created in the period 2007-2009.

Although the roadmap is not clear, WMS support is available for Open Geodata portal to select parties as well ("Currently access to WMS and WFS we have developed is limited, so be sure that the equipment that we can withstand the increased traffic"): http://geodata.gov.gr/geodata/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=2&Itemid=6
column26: We could not find any links or export/extract functionality for bulk data.
column29: Data from the Open Geodata portal is licensed CC-BY 3.0. Terms of use of orthophoto data are linked as follows.
column33: New data is pushed to the Geodata portal about every month.
column34: It seems there is continuing support for online maps both to meet the OGP requirements as well as internally for the integraton of data services, e.g. the memorandum of cooperation on geodata from 2010: http://geodata.gov.gr/open-geodata/images/mnhmonio_geodata.doc
column35: The web sites are well indexed and can be found through search engines.

column15:
The Hellenic Cadastre is a unified and constantly updated system of information that records the legal, technical and other additional details about real estate properties and the rights on them. http://www.ktimatologio.gr/sites/en/cadastralsurvey/Pages/MpuNFMi98NlPs1QZ_EN.aspx

column20: http://linked-statistics.gr/ is provided by the Institute for the Management of Information Systems and delivers socio-economic and socio-demographic data, made available as csv or excel files by the Hellenic Statistical Authority (ELSTAT), as Linked Open Data (LOD). Linked statistics provides semantically rich statistical data and connects ELSTAT to the LOD cloud.

column15:
Þjópskrá Íslands / Land Registry of Iceland [1] 

##Sources
[1] http://www.skra.is on 2014-11-3
column18:
Ownership of land is currently not available as open data. Clarification answer from Katrín Hólm Hauksdóttir, Data processing, Geo-Information Department, Registers Iceland [1]: 
Today the registration of land is arranged in such a way that the new number of the property is registered in the database of the National Registry of Iceland and the ownership is the same as the prior registered owner of the land. This file is a text file and it is possible to buy the data. 
Statistics Iceland also defines land properties in a spatial database. The ownership of land is not part of these data, but it is possible to connect the demarcation of land to the registration of ownership. You can buy this dataset from Statistics Iceland. In the near future it is possible that data on land assets/properties (i.e. excluding the registration of ownership ) will be made available on opingogn.is
It is also possible to connect access address data to the ownership of land in the same way, there is a list of landowners down on each access address.
The ownership of land is not a part of the open records, partly because of privacy but additionally because Registers Iceland depends on their income from selling data. If, therefore, the register of land assets will be made available on opingogn.is the ownership of the land will not be part of the data.

Link to access address data: http://opingogn.is/is/dataset/stadfangaskra

[1] email Katrín Hólm Hauksdóttir, May 27 2014

column15: Registrar of Companies, Ministry of Corporate Affairs, Government of India.
column18: Registration with the Registrar of Companies, Ministry of Corporate Affairs, Government of India is only for those private limited or public limited companies that are registered under the Companies Act. There are two other levels of business organisations - small vendors / outlets and partnership firms - both of which are governed by the respective state governments where they operate. This second set of data is not available at all, either as open data, or otherwise.
column23: PDFs

column15: The two Houses of Parliament
column18:
This data is haphazardly distributed. The respective websites of the two houses of Parliament carry some information on the bills introduced and passed. Each Government Ministry's or department's website carries the laws it is supposed to administer, or operate under. They often put up draft bills for public discussion.

Bills are not necessarily available in open format but other data related to the parliament is available
column19:
Not available at a single source. Each Government ministry and department website carries the list of laws it administers, or operates under, as also the draft bills meant for inputs, comments and suggestions from the people. At the state level, the information, again, is available on the website of the department concerned.
Lok Sabha http://164.100.47.4/newlsbios_search/NewAdvsearch.aspx

A useful link for a part of the legislation data in India, especially on the pending bills in the Parliament is a private think tank PRS legislative research:

column15: Italian Ministry of Health (www.salute.gov.it)
column18: In Italy, hospital discharge records (SDO, Scheda di Dimissione Ospedaliera) are one of the main sources of information concerning health data. Every hospital fills in and sends to its own region a SDO record for each patient admitted to the hospital. The Ministry of Health checks and puts together the data sets from each region into a national one (more info http://www.salute.gov.it/portale/temi/p2_6.jsp?lingua=italiano&id=1232&area=ricoveriOspedalieri&menu=vuoto).

column15:
Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism (1) and the Geospatial Information Authority of Japan (2)

##Sources
(1) http://tochi.mlit.go.jp/english/generalpage/5608 Accessed on 2014-11-07
(2) http://www.gsi.go.jp/ Accessed on 2014-11-06
column18:
Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism Land is responsible for the National Land Survey (1). Regardind data collection, Municipalities are responsible for the registration of their Land Survey and the resulting data are integrated into the National Spatial Data Infrastructure (2) managed by the Geospatial Information Authority. Cadastral parcel boundaries constitute one of the layers available with the map data and can be therefore downloaded from the Geospatial Information Authority website at http://fgd.gsi.go.jp/download/ (registration needed). There is however no evidence of other land registry information available such as owner, surface, etc.

##Sources
(1) http://tochi.mlit.go.jp/english/land-policies/national-land-survey-land-policies Accessed on 2014-11-07
(2) https://www.fig.net/pub/proceedings/korea/full-papers/pdf/session16/oki-oshima.pdf Accessed on 2014-11-07

column20:
At, for example, hackathons, the data will be made open. "There's a need for more accessible open data," says programmer Soren Jones. "For example, the Japan Tourism Agency publishes statistics in formatted Excel files that need processing before they can be worked with." (1)

Source:
(1)Shintaro Eguchi, member of the Open Knowledge Foundation Japan and co-founder of Code for Japan, interviewed online in Tokyo on June 10.

column15: Japanese public procurement is undertaken in a decentralized way by each procuring entity on its own.
column18:
Japanese public procurement is undertaken in a decentralized way by each procuring entity on its own. There is no national procurement agency or the like. Though, there are central information sources and databases for companies to search for tenders (1). There is a public procurement portal managed by the Japan External Trade Organization but there is no data on awarded contracts (2). Some Ministries provide awarded contracts information on their website. We could find such data on the following ones: Ministry of Education, Culture, Science, Sports and Technology (3), Ministry of Environment (4), Ministry of Foreign Affairs (5) and Ministry of Defense (6).

##Sources
(1) ftp://ftp.cordis.europa.eu/pub/innovation-policy/studies/4_japan.pdf Accessed on 2014-11-07
(2) http://www.jetro.go.jp/cgi-bin/gov/gove010c.cgi Accessed on 2014-11-07
(3) http://www-gpo3.mext.go.jp/MextKokyoHP/list/zp010101.asp Accessed on 2014-11-14
(4) http://www.env.go.jp/kanbo/chotatsu/tekisei/h25.html Accessed on 2014-11-14
(5) http://www.mhlw.go.jp/shinsei_boshu/choutatsujouhou/ Accessed on 2014-11-14
(6) http://www.mofa.go.jp/policy/economy/procurement/ Accessed on 2014-11-14
(7) http://www.chotatujoho.go.jp/csjs/pr006/ProInfoSearchEngInitAction.do?pctKind=06 Accessed on 2014-11-14

column18:
Committee for management of land resources and its local subsidiaries and state enterprisers like Republican State Entreprise “Scientific and Production Center of Land Cadastre” provide this data for citizens on paid basis and for state bodies for free according to the law: "If land registry information does not contain state secrets and other restrictions are public and available to interested individuals and entities on a fee basis. Provision of information to the state bodies by land cadastre authorities carried out free of charge at the expense provided for this purpose budget." (Article 158, Land Code)  http://www.kazlands.kz/en

Interested individuals have to apply to local land committee.

column34: The datasets are available and mostly up-to-date but their publication is an one-shot. No syncronisation between them exists especially between the different languages of the website (thus, for ex., data from the English side of the website is outdated and relative to 2011 at best while the data on the Russian side of the website is from 2014). No metadata is published either. Updates are unclearly explicited. No publicly accessible information was identified regarding means to sustain further data publication. Lastly, sometimes data is released as PDFs or DOCs or even as .RAR of Excel sheets.

column18: The data set includes information on Acts, Bills, Constitution, Amendments, among other legislative instruments and tools
column23:
The Kenya Law database appears to be driven by underlying XML files (http://www.kenyalaw.org:8181/exist/kenyalex/index.xql), but it only provides download options in PDF format. Providing XML downloads should be possible, but no full database dump could be located. 

Links to copies of published laws are given in PDF and Word formats.

column15:
Ministry of Transport and Infrastructure - http://www.transport.go.ke/

The government rail agency does hold timetable information, but this can only be accessed at offices of the rail agency.
column18:
The government does not hold detailed public transport data because there is no widespread public transport system. The transport routes in Kenya's matatu and bus transport industryis dynamic with constant shifts in routes and service (1).

A pilot project has generated GTFS data for the Rift Valley Railway, but this does not appear to be central government supported (2).

(1): http://opengov.newschallenge.org/open/open-government/submission/digital-matatus-developing-open-data-for-informal-transit-systems/
(2): https://www.opendata.go.ke/Transport-and-Communication/Rift-Valley-Railways-data/6hdc-7pkq
column20: http://www.digitalmatatus.com/ provide GTFS data for the Nairobi Matatu network.

column18:

However, this information on the Kenya National Bureau of Statistics is available in the statistical abstracts.

At the time of research verification a number of Government of Kenya websites had been taken offline due to security issues.

However, Kenya Open data portal has information on health performance. It includes information on kenya health facilities, immunization rates, population sleeping under mosquito nets, health spending, among others

Public Procurement Oversight Agency

Despite the fact that most of the agencies or Ministries websites in Kenya have a link to tenders, The Public Procurement Oversight Agency is the central agency responsible for issues of tendering. Others with relevant data may include: Directorate of Commerce, Central Bank of Kenya, Kenya National Highways Authority, Kenya Revenue Authority

column15: Ministry of Lands, Housing and Urban Development through the Department of Surveys. The department in collaboration with the National Statistics Office and a number of technical Ministries are managing Malawi Spatial Data portal that has information on Maps of Malawi.

column15: The National Statistical Office of Malawi is the main government department responsible for the collection and dissemination of official statistics.
column18: There is information on Population and Housing census
column24: The National Statistical Office link to the Countrystat Malawi service, and to Malawi Census Info sites. CountryStat provides access to a number of census derived indicators through an online interface, with downloads offered. A 'Census CD' ISO image is also provided for download, which when extracted contains Excel tables of aggregated data for many key indicators.
column27: The Population and Housing census reports can free be downloaded at free costs

column15:
Registrar of Companies under the Ministry of Industry and Trade 

Malawi’s Department of the Registrar General.
column18:
It is difficult to reveal the characteristics of the data as it is not available online. However, the literature suggests that data should be available in the Registrar of companies - Ministry of Industry and Trade has disclosed that it will be registering companies electronically to enable those residing far from cities to register their companies online.
Minister of Industry and Trade Sosten Gwengwe said this on Tuesday in Parliament when presenting the Companies Bill that introduces provision for the office of the Registrar of Companies that had been drafted in tandem with Business Registration Act passed last year - http://allafrica.com/stories/201306280300.html

column18:
(1) Malaysia Geo-Portal offers a searchable catalogue of metadata describing geo datasets offered by various agencies across Malaysia. However, not all metadata contain direct access to the datasets - most link to the actual agencies' websites and describe the protocols and red-tape required to access them. There do exist certain metadata containing KML, JSON access but not widespread.

(2)
Lots of data viewers exist:
http://1malaysiamap.mygeoportal.gov.my/
http://sismaps.jpbdselangor.gov.my/PenggunaAwam/rtShahAlam/default.htm

Access to these may be accessed via Malay-language websites

All the information related to land administration is available through the above office. The responsibility is rightly decentralized to the district level office though for local land management. column16:
Digital mapping data is not available for the country. The last update of the map of the country is extremely old - 50 years - but the National Geographical Institute (IGM) is planning to map the country with the support of EU funds. This would also be the opportunity to create a digital mapping system of the country (1)(2).

INSTAT provides with basis statistics data such as the results for the last census. The website of the institute also refers to Annual Statistics Book for years 2011 and 2010 but the reports cannot be downloaded. There is also a project to archives statistics data with support from PARIS21 and GOPA/UE but the dedicated website do not offer any dataset (1).

##Sources
(1) http://www.afristat.org/nadamali/index.php/acceuil Accessed on 2014-09-11

column18:
The Ministry of Finance provides information on the 2004 (1) and 2013 (2) budgets dedicated minisites built from CDROM version. Tables with planned revenues and expenditures are available. Expenditures are classified by entities not by programs. Budget is also available in brochure format for citizen.

column16:
Budget minisites provide information on budget execution reports for the previous year but this are aggregated figures only. 2014 budget website provides only mid-year budget execution for 2013 mid-year execution (1). Same for 2013, it only provides mid-year execution for year 2012 (2).

column16:
There are some evidences on the INSTAT website that the institute already published a register of company containing 5000 entities (1). But this dataset could not be found on the website or on another website. Moreover, there is no evidence that there is a specific registry for Company data. Information on companies seems to come from dedicated but irregular company census (2). Finally, there is a project to implement a National Number for Companies and thus create a national registry (3) but there is no evidence the data are already collected.

We are about to experience in some areas the rise of real-time data from the mobile phone, but this is not yet available in open data."

column15: Ministry of Education
column16:
No evidence that the government is collecting data on education. The Ministry of Education does not have any website and the page on Education on the Statistics Agency website is empty (1). Some data on education on the country are available from third party entities but only in aggregated levels and is often dated (2)(3). 

##Sources
(1) Institut National de la Statistique du Mali, http://instat.gov.ml/voir_domaine.aspx?dom=6 Accessed on June 26, 2014
(2) Data World Bank, School enrollment, primary, Year 2012, http://data.worldbank.org/country/mali Accessed on July 22, 2014

Ministry of Environment and Sanitation (1):

##Sources
(1): http://www.environnement.gov.ml/
column16:
There is a website dedicated to sanitation and pollution managed by the Ministry of Environment and Sanitation but it is empty (1). There is a national Forestry information system SIFOR. It is currently being used amongst other things to monitor changes in vegetation cover due to forestry projects in the Mopti, Segou and Kayes regions, implemented by NGOs (including Sahel Eco) and funded by the EU-AGCC (Alliance Globale. The website contains some documents such as forest surveys and fire reports but no new document has been published since April 2013 (2).

##Sources
(1) DONNEES DE L'ASSAINISSEMENT - POLLUTION - NUISANCE MALI, http://bd.stp.gov.ml/donnenviron/assainis.php Accessed on June 26, 2014
(2) SIFOR, http://sifor-mali.net/ Accessed on July 22, 2014

column15: The National and Independent Commission for Elections (CENI).
column18: The National and Independent Commission for Elections (CENI) of Mali is responsible for the publication of national election results but the agency does not have any website and there is no evidence it provided the results online. EU Commission published a report on the election including a table with aggregated results http://www.eueom.eu/files/pressreleases/other/RAPPORT-FINALANNEXESA-F_MOE-UE-MALI-2013-lection-prsidentielle_fr2.pdf Accessed on July 22, 2014

column15:
The country's Ministry of Housing and Land Development is responsible for the Cadastre dataset (1).

##Sources
(1) ttp://nao.gov.mu/English/Pages/Ministry-of-Housing-and-Land-Development-.aspx Accessed on 2014-09-22
column18:
The data is not available for online access. Mauritius has the Land Administration, Valuation and Information Management System (LAVMIS) with Cadastre one of the subsystems. Via the Cadastre system a digital map detailing parcels of land in Mauritius, with each parcel identified by a Parcel Identification Number (PIN) is registered. Thus, from the URLs listed below the country has a national land registration database (1,2).

References:
(1) News- Mauritius: new land administration system for improved urban planning, infrastructure development, environmental management & production of national statistical, http://www.astrium-geo.com/en/176-mauritius-case-study, Accessed on 2014-09-22
(2)Ministry of Housing and Land Development, http://nao.gov.mu/English/Pages/Ministry-of-Housing-and-Land-Development-.aspx, Accessed on 2014-09-22.

column15:
A detailed digital map of the country is provided by the National Institute of Statistics and Geography INEGI (1). It is available as an online tool and as a downloadable application. The map contains detailed information that lets you measure distances, locate roads, geological features, etcetera. I am citing it is not provided as open data due to the fact that the application has system requirements including the use of Windows platforms.

(1)  www.inegi.org.mx

column15:
Detailed budget information is available through the Budget Transparency Portal maintained by the Finance Ministry (Secretaría de Hacienda y Crédito Público - www.shcp.gob.mx). Some of the information is available in open data formats, other in PDFs. I checked with budget transparency expert and IBP partner Diego de la Mora who confirmed major datasets are available in open data format, thus the response given to the question.

The Mexican government also published a especial portal http://www.transparenciapresupuestaria.gob.mx/
column29: commercial use is explicitly forbidden

column15: Detailed government spending information is available through the Budget Transparency Portal maintained by the Finance Ministry (Secretaría de Hacienda y Crédito Público - www.shcp.gob.mx). Information is available in open data formats (double-checked info with budget transparency expert and IBP partner Diego de la Mora)

column15:

Legislative information is officially published in the Diario Oficial de la Federación which is managed by the Interior Ministry (Secretaría de Gobernación – www.segob.gob.mx). Information is searchable and available in .html as well as PDF at http://www.ordenjuridico.gob.mx/leyes.php .

column15:
Public transport data for railways is not available (information generated by the federal level). Detailed information on bus timetables depends on each transportation system and is generated at the state and city level (4) (5). Information not found through Web survey. Expert consulted confirmed this result. (1). There are non-official websites that provide intercity bus information (2) (3)

(1): Interview with Juan Manuel Casanueva. Executive Director Social-TIC. June 13, 2014.
(2): http://horariodebuses.com/mx/
(3): http://mexicoautobuses.com
(4): http://www.nl.gob.mx/?P=aet_mapa_rutas_interactivo
(5): http://www.ciudadmexico.com.mx/transporte.htm

column15:
At least two agencies within the Mexican government provide health-related data. 

The National Institute of Statistics and Geography (INEGI – www.inegi.org.mx) provides the following information in several formats.

-	Levels of vaccination available in .xls (http://www3.inegi.org.mx/sistemas/sisept/default.aspx?t=msal29&s=est&c=22556) 
-	Levels of access to health care including insured patients in public facilities (IMSS and ISSSTE) available in .xls (http://www3.inegi.org.mx/sistemas/temas/default.aspx?s=est&c=21702) 
-	Causes of death in public and private hospitals available in .xls
http://www3.inegi.org.mx/sistemas/temas/default.aspx?s=est&c=21702
-	Reasons for doctor visits and hospitalizations in public and private hospitals available in .xls 
http://www3.inegi.org.mx/sistemas/temas/default.aspx?s=est&c=21702

The National System for Health Information (Sistema Nacional de Información en Salud - http://www.sinais.salud.gob.mx/) has an open data catalogue that includes only the following information:
-	CLUES (directory of health facilities)
-	CLUES KMZ (directory of health facilities)
-	Hospital Discharges
-	Maternal Mortality
-	Births

Available here: http://www.sinais.salud.gob.mx/basesdedatos/cat_datosabiertos.html

The Mexican Open Data portal also provides a couple of datasets

- http://catalogo.datos.gob.mx/dataset?sort=score+desc%2C+metadata_modified+desc&ext_prev_extent=-121.28906250000001%2C7.013667927566642%2C-82.6171875%2C38.8225909761771&organization=salud&q=&ext_bbox=
column19:
-	Levels of vaccination available in .xls (http://www3.inegi.org.mx/sistemas/sisept/default.aspx?t=msal29&s=est&c=22556) 
-	Levels of access to health care including insured patients in public facilities (IMSS and ISSSTE) available in .xls (http://www3.inegi.org.mx/sistemas/temas/default.aspx?s=est&c=21702) 
-	Causes of death in public and private hospitals available in .xls
http://www3.inegi.org.mx/sistemas/temas/default.aspx?s=est&c=21702
-	Reasons for doctor visits and hospitalizations in public and private hospitals available in .xls 
http://www3.inegi.org.mx/sistemas/temas/default.aspx?s=est&c=21702

SINAIS data available here: http://www.sinais.salud.gob.mx/basesdedatos/cat_datosabiertos.html

http://www.ancfcc.gov.ma/FR/PagePrincipale.php
column20: No. The data appears to only be available to order.

column15:
The High Commissioner for Planning (Haut Commissariat au Plan, HCP) of the Kingdom of Morocco is responsible for the statistics. More precisely, the Statistics Directorate (Direction de la statistique(1) at the HCP.

(1): http://www.hcp.ma/Direction-de-la-statistiquea716.html
column18: The data is diverse but generally outdated and provided mostly as PDFs or Word documents although Excel sheets also exist.
column19:
These are general indices but only as images http://www.hcp.ma/Indices-statistiques_r102.html
Employment, unemployment data http://www.hcp.ma/downloads/Activite-emploi-et-chomage-premiers-resultats-annuel_t13036.html
Demography and gender http://www.hcp.ma/downloads/Demographie-Genre-et-developpement-aspects-socio-demographiques-et-culturels-de-la-differenciation-sexuelle_t13087.html
An interactive interface to explore 2004 census data is also available at  http://www.hcp.ma/Recensement-general-de-la-population-et-de-l-habitat-2004_a633.html

Also see http://www.data.gov.ma/data/fr/organization/haut-commissariat-au-plan
column24: Most of the data is on web pages and in PDF, but some Excel sheets do exist.
column26: Regardless of the file type, each of the files needs to be downloaded individually.
column27: Anyone can access and download the files for free.
column29: Copyright by the HCP
column31: 2013 for the Budget, older for other datasets (2006 for demography of elderly, 2004 for general demography).
column34: Many of the datasets requiring regular updates are published as one-off 'shots', their update mechanism is not clearly identified and their formats vary.
column35: Datasets are not immediately findable as the website lacks ergonomy and features images more prominently than datasets themselves.

column15:
Ministry of Economy and Finances (1).


(1): http://www.finances.gov.ma/
column18:
All the datasets it hosts are XLS, DOC, PDF, thus not all are machine-readable.
More specifically, all the datasets relating to finances and budget are in XLS format and available on both the MoF portal (http://www.finances.gov.ma/fr/Pages/Statistiques.aspx?Active=ICCM&m=vous%20%C3%AAtes? ) and on data.gov.ma (http://www.data.gov.ma/data/fr/group/finance ).

Yet, these are mostly outdated: seemingly, only one dataset presents the budget for 2012 and 2013, all the others reach 2011 at best.

Lastly, it is noteworthy to provide more detailed information on the Citizen Budget (Budget Citoyen, http://www.finances.gov.ma/fr/Pages/Budget-citoyen.aspx?m=Loi%20de%20finances%20et%20Budget ). It is available under PDF on the Ministry of Finances website (in French: [http://www.finances.gov.ma/Docs/2014/DB/bcfr2014.pdf](http://www.finances.gov.ma/Docs/2014/DB/bcfr2014.pdf) ; in Arabic: [http://www.finances.gov.ma/Docs/2014/DB/bcara2014.pdf](http://www.finances.gov.ma/Docs/2014/DB/bcara2014.pdf) ) and is up to date (2014).
column20: There are parts of the data available through floussna.ma (See http://www.floussna.ma/ (inactive) and the World Bank (https://finances.worldbank.org/fr/countries/Morocco ). Lastly, a dataset is available on OpenSpendint (https://openspending.org/floussna2014?_view=default) labelled for 2014, but it is unlikely the numbers are really for 2014 as the data itself is not available elsewhere in the first place.
column21:
http://www.data.gov.ma/data/fr/group/finance
Citizen Budget is only available as PDF: http://www.finances.gov.ma/fr/Pages/Budget-citoyen.aspx?m=Loi%20de%20finances%20et%20Budget
column26: Each file needs to be downloaded individually.
column27: Anyone can view and download the files for free and without prior login.
column29: Copyright by the Ministry of Economy and Finances. The Open Data portal is also indicated "Copyright 2014" and the page "License" gives an Error 404.
column30: Bottom of respective pages. Also: http://www.data.gov.ma/fr/licence
column34: Files are published on a per-spreadsheet basis on different websites, without syncronisation and metadata. Thus, the open data portal (other than its discrepancy regarding licensing) comes out as a placeholder for Excel sheets which are uploaded as one-shots.
column35: It is straightforward once the person is on the respective website: all categories and links are clearly labeled on every page.

Lybia1.softwarecentre.ma is a subdomain of Softwarecentre.ma which is the company of Moroccan entrepreneur Tarik Nesh-Nash. Tarik is the person behind Floussna2014 (previous link). He published the Floussna-2014.csv on his website. The link is broken though.

The explanation below the form is that you may access these, but to have them as well as the detailed information on the company, the visitor has to pay.

column15: General Secretariat of the Government; the Ministry of Justice
column18:
The General Secretariat of the Govt has several texts of existing/promulgated laws (The Constitution, Financial and Budget laws, Labour law, Family law, etc.) and many more of draft bills ("Projets de textes diffusés aux membres du gouvernement", http://www.sgg.gov.ma/Projetsdetextesl%C3%A9gislatifsetr%C3%A9glementaires.aspx ). 

I was not able to identify such documentation on the Ministry of Justice website (www.justice.gov.ma ), yet the ADALA (http://adala.justice.gov.ma/AR/home.aspx) database seems to be the focal point where legislation content is published.
column19:
On: http://www.sgg.gov.ma/Accueil.aspx; see http://www.sgg.gov.ma/L%C3%A9gislation.aspx and http://www.sgg.gov.ma/CodesTextesLois.aspx for a few promulgated laws; for draft bills ("Projets de textes diffusés aux membres du gouvernement", see: http://www.sgg.gov.ma/Projetsdetextesl%C3%A9gislatifsetr%C3%A9glementaires.aspx

ADALA: http://adala.justice.gov.ma/AR/home.aspx

column18: The Ministry of Economy and Finances provides a payment balance sheet (covers 2006-2013) where exports to and imports from different countries are listed. Numbers remain high-level though (only summary per year per country). The Moroccan Investment Development Agency does not publish any data. The Customs have a page or two with summary tables with very few entries.
column19:
Data can be found at http://www.douane.gov.ma/web/guest
eg. http://www.douane.gov.ma/web/guest/chiffresdouane and http://www.douane.gov.ma/douaneChiffres/ECR_ChiffresDouane_1.jsf (gains; summary numbers provided up to June 2013)

Payment balance sheet data is available on data.gov.ma ("Echanges extérieurs et balance des paiements", 2006-2013)

column15: The Ministry of Interior
column18:
No website for the Ministry of Interior could be located. Also, the Ministry of Interior is not a producer of Data at the Open Data portal (www.data.gov.ma). The staff of Digital Economy direction, who are working on the Open Data portal told me (interview) that the Ministry of Interior collect data but doesn't share it with them to publish it on the Open Data portal.

Election results information on Wikipedia (1) cites a press release as the source of data, and no archive of election data could be located. 

(1): https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moroccan_general_election,_2011

column23: Contracts subjected to bids are announced as static web pages; on each, there is a link to a .zip file to be downloaded. The .zip contains all needed documents and all required forms. The other reports are solely available as files to download (DOCX, PDF).

column15:
Data exist but no unique entity is reponsible for the data. The Direcção Nacional de Geologia (1) is in charge of the geological data, but at the tie of this writing (2014-10-08) no data was available. The Administraçao nacional de estradas (entity in charge of roads) provides maps in PDF format (2). The government portal also provides maps in reports in PDF (3). Cenacarta (4) claims to be a national cartography service, although it is unclear if that is true. It provides maps in shp form.

column16:
Mozambique has one of the least developed Transport Infrastructure in the Southern African region: road density has been estimated at 0.05 kilo meters per square kilo meter(1). Mozambique’s connectivity among urban and 
economic clusters is quite limited, lacking linkages that connect parallel corridors to each other(2).The bus timetable posted by the KAYA KEWERU Shuttle service is meager and as such it cannot be considered as a transport time table(3).

Some basic statistics on accidents are provided by the National Institute of Roads [Instituto Nacional do Viaçao] (4).

References:
(1): Delegation of the European Union to the Republic of Mozambique, http://eeas.europa.eu/delegations/mozambique/eu_mozambique/tech_financial_cooperation/transport_infra/index_en.htm
(2): C. Dominguez-Torres,C. Briceño-Garmendia, Mozambique’s Infrastructure: A Continental Perspective, http://siteresources.worldbank.org/MOZAMBIQUEEXTN/Resources/AICD-Mozambique_Country_Report.pdf
(3): Moçambique Backpackers, http://www.mozambiquebackpackers.com/bus-timetables.html
(4): http://www.inatter.gov.mz/index.php/estatisticas/item/82-dados-estatisticos-do-inatter-2012

The Survey Department of the Ministry of Environmental Conservation and Forestry manage the creation of a national map(1), taking over from the colonial institutions which formerly mapped the country.

column18:
There is evidence that the department is transitioning to digital map management (1) though detailed information on the extent of digitization of the current maps could not be found.

The Survey Department web pages state that "All the topographic maps published by the Survey Department can only be available with the permission of Ministry of Defence. However, maps of Myanmar and maps of State/Region are publicly available."

(1): http://www.geoinformatics.com/blog/latest-news/myanmar-survey-department-purchases-ultramap-and-ultracam-eagle
column20:
The Myanmar Information Management Unit / MIMU is a service to the UN Country Team and Humanitarian Country Team, under the management of the UN Resident and Humanitarian Coordinator provide a states/divisions &Townships Overview map, while the myanmar map on openstreetmap shows the road infrastructure, etc. 

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs links to a Google Map rather than detailed government maps on their web pages: http://www.mofa.gov.mm/?page_id=444

column15:

(1): http://csis.org/publication/land-reform-critical-test-myanmars-government
column16:
"Because all land in Burma ultimately belongs to the state, citizens and organizations depend upon use-rights, but do not own land." (1)

Land has long been a politically and economically contentious issue in Myanmar and land laws set out multiple systems of registration, with substantial weaknesses that suggest no coherent land registration system exists. 

(1): http://usaidlandtenure.net/sites/default/files/country-profiles/full-reports/USAID_Land_Tenure_Burma_Profile.pdf

The CSOStat.gov.mm site is configured with an invalid SSL certificate which means many users cannot access it. The non-HTTPS version returns a 404 error.

The only other statistical data provided from the government that our research located was from the ministry of Health.

column16:
It is not possible to identify how far spend data is well managed inside the state. 

The World Bank report on Financial Management Information Systems (FMIS) and Open Budget Data (1) reports that Myanmar has minimal visibility or not information available on budgets, and that a FMIS is planned, but not implemented.


(1): Dener, C., & Min, S. Y. (2013). Financial Management Information Systems and Open Budget Data. The World Bank. doi:10.1596/978-1-4648-0083-2

column16:
It is not possible to identify how far spend data is well managed inside the state. 

The World Bank report on Financial Management Information Systems (FMIS) and Open Budget Data (1) reports that Myanmar has minimal visibility or not information available on budgets, and that a FMIS is planned, but not implemented.


(1): Dener, C., & Min, S. Y. (2013). Financial Management Information Systems and Open Budget Data. The World Bank. doi:10.1596/978-1-4648-0083-2

column15:
Directorate of Investment and Company Administration (1).

(1): http://www.dica.gov.mm/
column18:
Myanmar has two forms of business registration: "...business activities that need substantial investments as manufacturing, construction, mining, hotels & resorts, agriculture and transportation have to be registered under the Myanmar Foreign Investment Law (MFIL) through the Myanmar Investment Council (MIC). The Myanmar Companies Act (MCA) allows foreign service providers to register companies for other services." (2)

(1): http://www.interactivemyanmar.com/company-registration/ - Accessed 30th October 2014
column19: A company search form can be found from the menu options at http://www.dica.gov.mm/ and served in a frame from http://54.179.166.36/Dica//Organization/CompanyList offering a search of companies.
column20: No data available was from any government agency, only a non-comprehensive lists of companies from third party such as http://www.list-company.com/company/list/i-r500370/Business-Myanmar-Asia.shtml and http://www.global-unions.org/spip.php?page=burma
column23: Only an searchable online database is provided. No bulk download appears to have been made available. However, the structure of the web pages providing data may make it possible to crawl.

column15: Namibia Statistics Agency
column18:
Population and Housing Censuses with information on demographic and socio-economic statistics including size, distribution, composition and other social and economic characteristics of the population as well as on household and housing amenities.

There is also data on GDP on quarterly basis (http://www.nsa.org.na/dataset/) under the national accounts link.
column24: SPSS files are provided for a number of household datasets. There is limited meta-data about the datasets provided.
column26: There are a number of 'raw' datasets, including household survey data, but these do not provide bulk access to key national statistics.
column27: The data on the GDP can easily be downloaded without any charge.
column29: Website states 'NSA © 2014, All rights reserved'
column34: The data set is sustainable as it is of various years ranging from 2008 to 2014 with their respective quarters
column35: The data can easily be discovered under the national accounts link - http://www.nsa.org.na/dataset/

column15: Netherlands’ Cadastre, Land Registry and Mapping Agency
column19:
http://www.kadaster.nl/web/Themas/Open-data.htm
(http://www.nationaalgeoregister.nl)

The first site gives an overview of all openly available datasets, whereas the second source indexes all kinds of geodata.
column24: Vector and raster data are provided. The vector data (TOP10NL) has a resolution of 1:10.000 and is provided in gml format. I have inspected the vector data here and given the link for one map square out of the selection page.
column26: The dataset is 1,7 GB big and contains all necessary geo and metadata. One can either download a bulk version for the entire country (chunkdata), or one devided into several map squares (kaartbladtotaal).
column29: CC-BY-3.0 NL
column33:
At least annual updates (1). The data has been published in an open form since 2012.

(1) Source: https://www.pdok.nl/nl/producten/pdok-downloads/basis-registratie-topografie/topnl/topnl-historie
column34: Appears thoroughly sustainable, detailed data in easy zip downloads, history page easy to find.
column35: Started out from kadaster.nl, which has a very visible "open data" menu point on it. After that, clicking myself to the most recent vector form of the map was not challenging.

column15: Netherlands' Cadastre, Land Registry and Mapping Agency
column19:
http://www.kadaster.nl/web/artikel/productartikel/Agrarische-transacties.htm (Registry of agricultural property transactions)
http://www.kadaster.nl/web/Themas/Registraties/BAG-1.htm (Key Registers for Addresses and Buildings (BAG))
http://www.kadaster.nl/web/Themas/Registraties/BRK.htm (Key Register Cadastre (BRK))
http://www.kadaster.nl/web/Zakelijk/Vastgoedcijfers/Downloads.htm (Property Dashboard)
column24:
This provides pretty thorough statistics on the number of property (number of sales, purchases, regions), mortgages (number, averages, total, also by region), land + lots (average price plots, prices of agricultural land), + auctions.

However, data on specific land ownership (BAG + BRK) is communal, and even though it is available via kadaster.nl, it is paid for. If I take the given examples for NZ and UK, I consider the found open data sufficient here.
column26: As the whole portal is on a paid-for and login basis, and the data is delivered on request, I cannot make qualified statements on this. However, it's a bit pointless anyway, as we are not talking about open data here.
column27: The agency charges per object, or in a subscription model.
column29: None found (assuming it is CY-BY 3.0 NL, as all the other data is under that license, and the data is on the general OD site (1)
column31:
2014-Q3 - the datasets actually don't have any additional information. The download of an example (1) showed the last reported quarter was Q2 2014. Therefore the data must be from at least July 2014. Another dataset (2) was updated on 2014-09-01 and featured monthly data including August 2014.

(1) http://prd-vastgoeddashboard.kadaster.nl/vgd/woningen/PrijsindexPerRegio.csv?years_back=9
(2) http://prd-vastgoeddashboard.kadaster.nl/vgd/agrarischegrond/gemiddeldeprijs.csv?years_back=9
column33: Yearly, quarterly, monthly - depending on dataset.
column34: As the data is easy to download and consists at least nine years going back, its basics are definitely sustainable. However, some of the data on the site lack metainfo.
column35: Starting out from the OD meta page on kadaster.nl, I quickly got to the statistics page.

column15: Centraal Bureau voor de Statistiek (Statistics Netherlands)
column18: Generally, Statistics Netherlands either offers clicking all the data through interactive tables or its open data site. In general, the site is quite helpful, however when looking for a comprehensive overview of statistical indicators, one has to click oneself through very many small steps, going through all the sub-branches of the info tree. The open data part of the site is a bit more helpful, as it offers directly downloading datasets. However it has a very detailed navigation, which means one also has to click a far way until one arrives at the hopefully right place.

column24: I'm referring to the 'population core figures' here, a number of other datasets are available on population  The data is offered in two csv versions, one as "raw" csv, the other as "dataset voor grafische weergave" (dataset for graphical representation). The api versions either show a direct api call (for apps) or an xml/atom feed, but not a direct bulk dataset.
column26: The exact way to bulk download the files is unclear to me, but ODATAFEED is explained at http://www.odata.org/documentation/odata-version-3-0/
column29: CC-BY 3.0 NL
column33: Some are published weekly, others monthly (population development, regional, by month), quarterly (macro-economic scoreboard), half-yearly (social monitor) or yearly (key figures, in English)
column34: Yes, definitely. All the data published, good documentation within the dataset description pages, archives, bulk download.
column35: Fairly easy. Via CBS website, took some time to find open data section. The OD Index gave some additional clues.

column15: Ministry of Finance
column18: A number of datasets can be found on the site rijksbegrooting.nl - some are just small calculations, some bigger tables. The site also contains subsidy recipients by ministry, a comparison of some budget details of government agency over 5 years + finally budgetary tables. The latter offers enough details to fit our goal here.
column20:
[WI-Researcher] NO: the OpenSpending project only offers (1) the basic dataset dataset "Begrotingsstaten" under "Dataset 1" (2)

[ODB-Researcher] However, the Webindex researcher who came to this verdict should take into account that Openspending is a voluntary project and doesn't guarantee full coverage. If volunteers analysed and processed further data available under (2), then this data were available under Openspending as well.

(1) https://openspending.org/datasets?territories=NL
(2) http://opendata.rijksbegroting.nl/
column24: The budgetary tables of the national budget of 2015 (Dataset 4a "Budgettaire tabellen Rijksbegroting") offers enough details to fit our aim here. The contain about 3000 lines and are offered in xlsx + ods format + and odt formated notes to the budgetary tables.
column26: I was not able to find bulk downloads or archive versions of the presently available data on the site. The only bulk download is for the 2015 proposal, not to be found in the open data section, and also only PDFs.
column29: CC-Zero
column33:
Annual - according to the accompanying odt document, the budget proposal for the following year is presented every year on the 3rd Tuesday in September ("Prince's Day"). I could not find a direct publication date. The budget for the present year (2014) was published on 2014-01-15 (1)

(1) https://data.overheid.nl/data/dataset/begrotingsstaten---ministerie-van-financi-n
column34:
Yes, as far as it appears from the publication cycles and frequency, and the data published, and the "About" page (1), the publication is sustainable.

(1) http://www.rijksbegroting.nl/algemeen/organisatie
column35: I had a look on the OD Census and on data.overheid.nl, which both didn't give me full tables, but the proper open data site on rijksbegroting.nl

column15: Ministry of Finance
column18:
For more info on the non-availability of open spending data, see the report by the National Court of Audit (1). They also advise that "information on public expenditure must be available at transaction level. At present the government provides an insight only into budgeted expenditure at policy article level." 

Further, the open data report cites the example of openspending.nl, which provides expenditure on a regional level (2).

(1) http://www.courtofaudit.nl/english/Publications/Audits/Introductions/2014/03/Open_Data_Trend_Report
(2) http://www.openspending.nl/
column23:
From what is available on http://opendata.rijksbegroting.nl/, neither the 'Begrotingsstaten' nor the 'Rijksrekening' are sufficient. The first is just a rather slim version of the budget, containing the different development stages of the spending (and revenues) for the years 2013 + 2014 (proposal, 1st passed version, 1st + 2nd supplementary version, realised version). For the year 2013 for instance, it contains about 250 spending and 250 revenue positions, some several millions or even billions big.
The second one is essentially a one-pager with government expenditure and revenue.

column15: Chamber of Commerce
column18: As of January 1, 2014, the services appear to have changed, also due to the merger with another Dutch organisation. Now, essentially no information except the overview of the search result with its name and address can be accessed.
column20: Part of the data is available through daily API scraping on https://openkvk.nl - however it cannot be verified if the data is still updated.
column23: We cannot tell, as I'd have to pay for access.

column20:

column24: The data feed is legally generated from official sources and maintained by the Open Knowledge Foundation Open Transport working group. From the description: " The transit data used is supplied by transit agencies via the legally sanctioned 'OpenGeo ND-OV loket', in a transmodel derived format. The transmodel-data is then converted by us in to GTFS."
column26: Essentially, it's the same. This represents a full account for the present year.
column29: CC0
column33: Daily, as far I could tell from looking at the dates of the downloaded GTFS data.

column15: DUO ("Dienst Uitvoering Onderwijs") of the Ministry of Education, Culture and Science
column18: Going through the different levels of the data offered takes a lot of time; it also shows that a database (text version) of all the data offered also exists in a further part of the website.
column24:
1) The number of examinees per pre-vocational (vmbo) school enclosing the ratings of average grades in the school, the national examination and the marks per subject.
2) The number of examinees per senior general secondary education (HAVO) school enclosing the ratings of average grades in the school, the national examination and the marks per subject.
3) The number of examinees per pre-university education (VWO) school enclosing the ratings of average grades in the school, the national examination and the marks per subject.
4) The number given lessons in secondary schools by subject, cluster courses, degree, job, sex, age, institution, administration (authority in charge) region.
column26: The data included is broken down to the nine areas reported on - each has a zip file including the data base in a ASCII text format
column29: CC-0
column34:
Rather sustainable, the data is published in a number of formats, regularly, is available for several years back, there is an update calendar (1). However, the bulk download is only available for the last year, and according to an external site (by a benchmarking company), the publication had been getting more and more delayed in the past. (2)

(1) http://data.duo.nl/organisatie/open_onderwijsdata/Images/publicatiekalender_tcm33-41598.pdf

column15: Centraal Bureau voor de Statistiek
column18: Statistics Netherlands provides aggregated data on crime statistics. The data comes from the police and the attorney general / public prosecutor, also from courts, on such cases which were settled in the first instance. The data referred to here is the "classic" one from the police.
column20: NO: no third party provider encountered

(1) the results for crimes recorded by the police. Also includes normalised figures (= per 100.000 inhabitants) - 2005-2013

column29: CC-BY 3.0 NL

column35: Fairly easy. Via CBS website, took some time to find open data section. The OD Index gave some additional clues.

column15: National Institute for Public Health and the Environment (RIVM)
column18:
A lot of data is available for the entire nation, also geo-located data on sensor networks are easy to find on data.overheid.nl. However the RIVM site is not so well organised, as some sub-sections lack the standard navigation and appear a bit insular. There's also the Netherlands Environmental Assessment Agency (PBL), which also does not help for direct, regionally granular data (1).

(1) http://www.pbl.nl/en/
column20: NO: no third party provider encountered
column24:
(1) Particulate matter (PM10), daily, with a number of measuring station from 1992 to 2013-12-31.
(2) Daily values of all Dutch measuring stations for PM10, SO2, NH3, CO, O3, NO. Download only possible per month
(3) Total Dutch emissions of greenhouse gases by both stationary and mobile sources, preliminary figures for 2013
column26:
To a certain extent the daily PM10 data (1) ranging back until 1992 can be considered as bulk.
The sensor data (2) is not downloadable as bulk
The Dutch emissions (3) can be downloaded in bulk a odata feed.
column29: Could not find any specific information on the data - I would have supposed it's CC0, but the general information in the disclaimer is: You may use everything when attributing, but not commercially.
column34: It appears to be sustainable, underlying data (daily measurement) has been collected very long; the output is sub-par, as the site for the measurement network does not give license info and does not allow downloading bigger portions (entire year or several years).
column35: Looking through the "publication" part directed to by the WI research didn't help much, nor did data.overheid.nl. First an additional search redirected me to the further offerings of the RIVM website.

column15: Electoral Council (Kiesraad)
column18:
The election result database is available in an interactive form. The a bit strange part is that one is only shown a national result table, but actually downloads all the voting districts as well.
Also, some election results, but not the most recent ones, are available via the open data site of the Statistical Office (1) This might be interesting for retrieving historical overviews in somewhat bulk version (2)

(1) http://opendata.cbs.nl/dataportaal/portal.html
(2) http://opendata.cbs.nl/dataportaal/portal.html#_la=nl&tableId=70172NED&_theme=498
column24: Entry site for second chamber (House of Representatives) results. Several selections can be made, if one chooses all (or makes no selection), one can download a csv that contains all voting districts (and all elections, if several ones were in the same year).
column26: To my understanding, only being able to download data for one election, and this too only after clicking a number of elements, is not bulk. If I have to do this for every year and every election, even less.
column29: Could not find license - the help site only refers to texts and images authored by the election commission, thus I conclude that the data on the site is public domain.
column31:
Presumably 2014-05-30 - as the final results of the European elections were announced (1)

(1) https://www.kiesraad.nl/nieuws/uitslag-verkiezing-leden-europees-parlement-van-22-mei-2014
column34: Data reaches back very far, can be retrieved rather easily, however not by just clicking a number of files. The downloaded csv always get the generic name 'results'.
