column15:
Land Registry and Cadaster General Directorate (1) under The Ministry of Environment and Urban Planning (2).

1. http://www.tkgm.gov.tr/
2. http://www.csb.gov.tr/
column18:
Spatial Property System (MEGSİS) has been developed by Land Registry and Cadaster General Directorate, but it doesn't provide actual information on ownership:
http://cbs.tkgm.gov.tr/parselsorgu.aspx. In 2013 researchers noted that a cadastral project remains underway to generate a full national dataset, and reviews show substantial progress towards a comprehensive cadastral register (http://www.tkgm.gov.tr/en/content/completion-establishment-cadastre)

The system makes possible to search cadastral data over digital map of the country.  Spatial data is presented visually. Within this module, the layers section, navigation and drawing tools are located.

The system is for using on the internet and e-government system. It is not possible to download and use land ownership data set. Some additional information about the  system: http://cbs.tkgm.gov.tr/dokumanlar/MEGSIS_HARITAUYGULAMALARI_DOKUMANI_S01.pdf

column15: Turkish Statistical Institute (Türkiye İstatistik Kurumu) (http://www.turkstat.gov.tr/)

column15: Local transport is organized by the city municipalities. For example, in the capital of Turkey Ankara, Ankara Metropolitan Municipality publishes public transport details : http://www.ego.gov.tr/
column18:
Some public transport conducts by Municipalities, others conduct by private companies. Therefore, there are no any centralized timetable data. However, there are individual transport timetable for one particular city. For example, Istanbul metropolitan municipality publishes public transport timetable :http://www.iett.gov.tr/
Railways are controlled by the government owned State Railways: http://www.tcdd.gov.tr/
There is no centralized transport timetable data. Some big cities publish timetable only in HTML and jpg format.
For example:http://www.ego.gov.tr/parts/egohareketsaatleri.asp?NO=115&KALKIS=&VARIS=

column15: Ministry for Environment and Water
column18:
Data releases from the Ministry for Environment and Water are exclusively related to animal wealth, fisheries, and agricultural output. While there are several government and non-government organisations involved in environmental awareness programs and community action programs, activities are generally in areas such as energy consumption, marine debris, waste reduction, and paper consumption. Furthermore, no information on carbon emissions, emission of pollutants (e.g. carbon monoxides, nitrogen oxides, particulate matter etc.), and deforestation was identified. These areas of intervention are not currently the focus of Ministry for Environment and Water open data releases, and, therefore, cannot be attributed to current environmental open data initiatives. 

Ministry for Environment and Water. (2014). Statistics http://www.moew.gov.ae/Portal/en/knowledge-and-statistics/statistics.aspx#page=1

column23: Data is actually a short list of votes per emirate, followed by a list of number of votes per candidate per emirate. The page with charts has only images of charts.

column15: Government tenders are issued at the organizational level. A limited exception is Dubai's Tejari system which has attempted to aggregate government tenders from Dubai. However, contract awards data are not made public. Since business licensing is at the Emirate level, it may not make sense to have a national portal since businesses registered in one emirate are not able to contract with government entities in another emirate.

column18:
The Land Registry runs on a manual system of record keeping, though government has piloted the Computerized Land Register and Land Information System. This is an attempt to address the issue of the disorganized registry and enable an expedited storage, access and retrieval of land records to enhance service delivery. the Permanent Secretary in the Ministry of Lands, Housing & Urban Development points out that for the moment the registry still relies on the ‘human factor’ because putting the system in place and sustaining it is not cheap (1).

There is also evidence that the Ministry of Lands, Housing and Urban Development has data sets on land ownership though it is not published. For example, This is evident by the Land Information system in Masaka district where some land titles were no entered into the system as result of incomplete information on their land. Here is the link - http://www.mlhud.go.ug/publicnotices/phploaderLIS%20Masaka%20PROBLEMATIC%20FILES.pdf.php

(1) Gabindadde Musoke, 31st May 2013, “Computerizing the Uganda land registry”
http://www.independent.co.ug/column/comment/7838-computerising-the-uganda-land-registry
column20: No. However, there is a sample of land ownership information in pdf formats for masaka land owners who had incomplete information to enter their land reconds into the Land Information System - http://www.mlhud.go.ug/publicnotices/phploaderLIS%20Masaka%20PROBLEMATIC%20FILES.pdf.php

column18:
The data sets on the Uganda Bureau of Statistics website focus on a range of primary and secondary education performance indicators such as key education indicators, number of primary school orphans by sex, pupils with special needs, pupils primary leaving examination results by grade,literacy rates, among others.

The data set on the Ministry of Education and Sports is presented in Annual sector performance reports. The data sets are retrieved from Education Management Information Systems. The information includes total enrollment, primary and secondary school performance, teacher student ratio, number of orphans, pupils with special needs education, expenditures, among others.

column18:

British Geological Survey is the nodal agency responsible for advising government on all matters related to geoscience.
column24: "Strategi® provides a regional overview of the road network, railway lines, cities and wooded areas and is designed to support applications such as environmental analysis. This digital vector data product is the equivalent of Ordnance Survey’s 1:250 000 scale graphic maps." Available either as ESRI shapefile, DXF or MapInfo TAB. E-Mail with address has to be entered before being able to download the data, download links are sent by mail.

column15: Land Registry
column18:
Land Registry is the government agency holding land ownership data. Property ownership can be accessed online, a record's content cannot be viewed, however, but has to be downloaded for between 3 and 9 pounds, depending on the type (title register,  title plan, flood risk indicator). This data can also be downloaded in bulk as csv if paid for, either with a simple or a premium plan, varying in the update frequency. (1)

(1) https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/land-registry-data/public-data#commercial-corporate
column24: Data available in different packages, monthly ("transactions received at Land Registry in the period from the first to the last day of the corresponding month."), yearly and "Single file" (everything since 1995).
column26: "These include the transactions received at Land Registry from 1 January 1995 to the most current monthly data. The data is updated monthly and the average size of this file is 2.86 GB." Download as csv or txt

column33: monthly for the monthly overviews, yearly for the yearly file.

In some parts, the data is lacking regional coverage for Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland, this is the case for instance with the labour market statistics.

column29: All: Open Government License 2.0
column34:
In general: Yes, very sustainable. In particular, links that generate the most recent version of monthly or yearly statistics in the desired format are very smart. (1)

(1) http://www.ons.gov.uk/ons/datasets-and-tables/downloads/csv.csv?dataset=lms

(A side note on sustainability of data.gov.uk: At a first look, http://data.gov.uk/dataset/quarterly_national_accounts for the GDP appears as a bulk download possibility. However, the overview site does not lead to data, but to archived ONS sites. Access to data is only possible for the recent 2 years (until  Q4 2011) - yet most of the data is covered in the most recent version of the quarterly views of the GDP.)
column35: As selecting proper datasets in this area involves searching and looking through a lot of statistics, it was a bit difficult. For instance, data.gov.uk doesn't deliver any direct data links when looking for 'census 2011', only links to the ONS's specific sites (i.e. http://data.gov.uk/dataset/2011_census_). From these sites, following the links to 'reference tables' actually leads to data. Also it takes some time to understand that a lot of statistics don't only include a snapshot of, for instance, the labour market in a specific month, but range back more than 20 year. So the most recent version also is a bulk data version. However, a yearly version cannot be found in this cases.

column15:

(Office of Budget Responsibility)
column18: HM Treasury publishes the detailed data on planed public expenditure. However, it is not named 'budget' in any way, but is found under the abbreviation PESA. The most recent data (for 2014) does not exist on data.gov.uk (!) - the latest version available is from mid 2012. On gov.uk, the "Budget 2014: Documents" have nothing to do with data, unfortunately.
column20:
Data is republished by a number of agents, such as UK Public Spending (1)

(1) http://www.ukpublicspending.co.uk/
column24:
(1) The main document is "Chapter 1: Departmental budgets tables"
(2) The OSCAR database also contains planed expenditure
column26: The OSCAR database also contains planed expenditure, and the data available definitely qualifies as bulk.
column29: OGL v3
column34: As the data published in the COINS version proved to be rather difficult to read and interpret, the new system is supposed to make that easier. The publication is definitely sustainable in terms of availability, documentation etc.
column35: Actually, finding UK budget data proved to be one of the most difficult challenges I had yet. Also due to terminology reasons, I did not find proper data until I took the detour via ukpublicspending.co.uk/, which directed me to the proper source. Also difficult is a number of relaunch induced collateral URL damages on gov.uk, which makes a lot of older links useless.

column15: HM Treasury
column18: The Combined Online Information System (COINS) by HM Treasury is being replaced by the Online System for Central Accounting (OSCAR). Spending is found in OSCAR on a central level, and via data.gov.uk for each government agency on a transactional level (>500 or 25.000).
column20: Spending data is also displayed on sites such as http://www.ukpublicspending.co.uk/
column24:
(1) New OSCAR reporting data
(2) Gov't Spend > 500 or >25.000
column26: In case of spending >500/25.000 per department (2), each respective site has to be used. I chose the example of the Department of International Development, which features a large monthly time series (42 datasets, ranging back to 04-2011).
column29: OGL v3
column33:
OSCAR data: every three months
Government Spend: usually every month
column34: Availability and time ranging back appear quite solid.
column35: Finding ones way around spending data takes a bit of time, however after some accommodation, the British system appears to be quite reasonable to handle - especially because data.gov.uk functions as a real hub with good filtering possibilities.

column15: Companies House is agency responsible for company registration data
column18: Companies house provides two public datasets with basic data for free. These are quite voluminous, and in the case of submitted accounts data, rather difficult to process/manipulate.
column20: Also available via the government data website - http://data.gov.uk/dataset/basic-company-data
column24:
Regular snapshots containing basic data from the Companies House database. Split up into 5 zip files. It is updated every month within 5 days after the end of the previous month.
(2) Additionally, also accounts data can be freely downloaded in bulk zip files, containing individual data files of company accounts filed electronically. Available on daily basis for the last 3 months, older ones in monthly bulk files (2 b)
column26: Same data as in c) - can be considered as bulk.
column29: Crown Copyright - Attribution required
column34: Monthly updates, linked data, open publication, satisfactorily documented.
column35: A quick look at the Companies House site, then had a look at data.gov.uk, which quickly led to the public datasets.

column15: The National Archives (department of the Ministry of Justice)
column18: The Constitution of United Kingdom is available in several documents, court judgement, work of authorities, treaties
column24:
(1) Example of overview (Data Retention and Investigatory Powers Act 2014)
(2) As xml
(3) As rdf
(4) All General Public Acts as feed

On Formats: http://www.legislation.gov.uk/developer/formats
column26: Via the API and using feed functions: Yes. A direct download of all acts would not be that easy, but for every year should work, i.e. http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/1995/data.feed
column29: Open Government License 2.0
column31:
(1) 2014-10-07  - most recent legislation ("The M62 Motorway (Junction 22) (No. 2) (Temporary Prohibition of Traffic) Order 2014")
(2) 2014-09-06  - most recently updated act, (Data Retention and Investigatory Powers Act 2014), also used in c)

(1) http://www.legislation.gov.uk/uksi/2014/2688/contents/made/data.xml
(2) http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2014/data.feed
column33: As the dataset consists of numerous different laws, it is difficult to give one date here. However, a number of acts contains the pointer that they still have to be updated.
column34:
All legislative data is provided, URIs show where I am. Also pending changes are indicated and the impact of a certain law on others is displayed. What appears a bit strange is the fact that the data features of the site are not communicated on the site itself. For instance the developers site (1) could only be found via Google.

(1) http://www.legislation.gov.uk/developer/uris
column35: In general, it is quite easy to find information that legislative data is provided by legislation.gov.uk. However, finding documentation on the linked data aspect and the API is more difficult, as I could not directly find access points on the standard site. When googling for such info, I instantly found their developer page.
column37:
http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2009/23/section/20 (UK Marine and Coastal Access Act 2009)
http://www.legislation.gov.uk/changes/affecting/ukpga/2009/23 (impact on other acts)

column15:
Local Transport Authorities
Department for Transportation (NaPTAN)
Association of Train Operators
Traveline (partnership of transport operators and local authorities)
column18:
The data for the public transport is widely available through local authorities. 
Examples: Transport for London (government website), Traveline (private service provider)
Also the National Public Transport Access Codes (NaPTAN) are of help for data re-users, as they  provide the unique IDs for any point of access to public transport in GB.
Northern Ireland missing in theses datasets, privately operated coach services as well.

List of all known (more or the less) open data releases in the industry: http://nrodwiki.rockshore.net/index.php/OpenDataReleases
column24:
Both datasets require prior registration on the respective websites. Thus, full openness in terms of non-discriminating, open access to data is not given!

(1) Weekly updates on public transport timetables for bus, light rail, tram and ferry services in GB (not in Northern Ireland). However, Traveline requires registration before being able to download data. Registration is approved by an official.
(2) File contains service details of trains, buses and ferries as passed from TSDB. Format defined in CIF specification, as issued by Network Rail. (CIF = Common Interface)
column26:
Complete weekly update  of data in both cases - qualifies for bulk.
More on the data can be found under http://nrodwiki.rockshore.net/index.php/Main_Page
column27: Free - however, both pages require signing up, giving personal details and the proposed use. In case of ATOC, the membership is processed automatically with an instant confirmation link by mail, in case of TNDS, a staff member approves the resistration (or not.)
column29:
The licenses are both open, but the access to data is not provided openly - see c)

(1) Open Government License 2.0
(2) Creative Commons England and Wales Public Licence
column34: In general, yes. The companies
column35: Yes, via the OGD portal. Additional info via the OD Census.

column15: Office of National Statistics
column18:
The data mainly come from the ONS and is available via different outlets.
They are featured on data.gov.uk, where a range of trade statistics is available under the Open Government License.
HM Revenue and Customs maintains trade records as well
column24: The dataset contains a very vast time series with foreign trade data since 1975.
column26: The time series qualifies as bulk / raw data IMHO.
column29: Open Government License 2.0
column34: ONS thoroughly maintain the dataset, in diverse formats, and as it appears, on a long term basis.
column35: Rather easy via data.gov.uk. A ONS site search for "imports exports" would work as well.

column15:
Department of Health
National Health Service (NHS)
column18:
A large number of datasets (200+) is provided by the Department of Health on data.gov.uk. A lot of these datasets are on medical statistics, such as the prevalence of a certain disease. In terms of performance data, there seem to be some discontinuities on data.gov.uk - a datasets such as "NHS Inpatient and Outpatient Waiting Times, England" was last updated in 2011, containing data for 2010. A test for all DoH datasets containing 'waiting' delivered datasets with data from late 2012 in the most recent case. This might have to do with update cycles, also weekly data such as "A&E weekly" (3) contained the "week ending 17 March 2013" as most recent part. However, this has to do with the search mechanism. If one also chooses "Include datasets from sub-publishers", far more recent datasets are displayed (4). In some cases the publisher changes between DoH and NHS, as in (5) and (6).
NHS-related entries lead to specific NHS sites instead of allowing direct csv downloads.


(1) http://data.gov.uk/dataset/nhs_inpatient_and_outpatient_waiting_times_england
(2) http://data.gov.uk/data/search?q=waiting&publisher=department-of-health&sort=metadata_modified+desc#search-sort-by
(3) http://data.gov.uk/dataset/ae_weekly_data__
(4) http://data.gov.uk/data/search?q=wait&parent_publishers=department-of-health&sort=metadata_modified+desc#search-sort-by
(5) http://data.gov.uk/dataset/ambulance_quality_indicators_system_indicators_
(6) http://data.gov.uk/dataset/ambulance_quality_indicators_system_indicators__
column24: Chose the referral to treatment waiting times (2), the ambulance quality dataset (3) plus ambulance quality clinical datasets (4) - essentially, data.gov.uk leads to the specific NHS sites such as (5).
column26: In all cases, the data is available in depth and ranging back many years, at least until 2011 in the present NHS system.
column29: OGL, v3
column33: Monthly, with some time to be published, i.e. March data in October
column34: Data is published and updated quite regularly, available under an open license, and can be found easily on the OGD portal.
column35: After overcoming the restriction of also allowing sub-publishers, quite easy via keyworad such as 'quality' or 'waiting'.

column15:
Department of Education
School Performance Tables
column18:
Essentially, the most relevant data is provided at the school performance tables resource. However, statistics also can be found on gov.uk (1), such as on pupil abscence (2). Data.gov.uk also allows finding the Department of Education's datasets (3)

(1) https://www.gov.uk/government/statistics?departments%5B%5D=department-for-education
(2) https://www.gov.uk/government/statistics/pupil-absence-in-schools-in-england-autumn-2013-and-spring-2014
(3) http://data.gov.uk/publisher/department-for-education
column24:
Data for specific schools also can be filtered by different criteria on the landing page (1), the quick version however is going for bulk data on the download page, which allows the download for entire England on a number of subjects such as exam results, absence, census or school workforce.

(1) http://www.education.gov.uk/schools/performance/
column26:
Same site for both cases, an archive for earlier years exists:
http://www.education.gov.uk/schools/performance/2012/download_data.html
http://www.education.gov.uk/schools/performance/2011/download_data.html
etc.
column29: OGL v3
column31:
2014-03 
However, data is not given directly. Deduced from publication data included in pdfs.
column34: Definitely, as the data is published thoroughly in a similar way each year, in several formats, allowing bulk downloads as well as very granular selections.
column35: Very easy via the Department for Education, which features the link to the tables at the top of its site.

column15: Home Office (UK Police) + Scottish Government (Scottish Statistics)
column18:
Police - England, Wales and Northern Ireland - offer a street level overview including updates on which state the outcome is, such as "offender fined". Also available via API.

Scottish neighbourhood statistics are provided by the Scottish Government. However these data are far less granular and were not considered in the data evaluation.

NB: The ONS does not consider the data published by the UK police as compliant to its standards anymore (1)

(1) http://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-25831906
column20: https://www.ukcrimestats.com/ provides free access to the crime data for England, Wales and Northern Ireland
column24:
(1) Overview page
(2) Street-level crime and outcome data: csvs selectable by time and forces (+ outcome data)
(3) Annual Data Requirement = Police Recorded Crime and Police Outcomes
column26: Time selectable in months starting from December 2010. One big file containing "everything" can be created.
column29: OGL v3
column34:
Data is easily available and downloadable in open formats with clear navigation and a thorough documentation page (1)

(1) http://data.police.uk/about/
column35: Very simple via police.uk, then via the "use the data link".

column15: Department for Environment Food & Rural Affairs (DEFRA)
column18:
The UK Office for National Statistics keep the records for environmental accounts for the country
The Department for Environment Food & Rural Affairs publish national and official statistics relating to the environment, rural communities, food and farming.

The data available is strongly overview oriented, providing small data files (i.e. 40 KB xls files) - see (1).
For detailed data, one has to use the data archives by DEFRA, which involve some interaction, but allow for thorough downloads.

DEFRA claims having unified and simplified the publication cycle (2), yet more detailed data now seems to be more difficult to find.

(1) https://www.gov.uk/government/statistical-data-sets/env02-air-quality-statistics
(2) https://www.gov.uk/government/collections/air-quality-and-emissions-statistics
column24: Data available on numerous pollutants, such as carbon monoxides, sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, particulate matter in various levels (daily mean, peaks) and various temporal and local granularities.
column26: Various selections can be made - yet bulk downloads with pre-packed datasets are not available. And selections only allow for 256 columns and a certain number of rows.
column29: Crown Copyright / OGL v3
column33: Daily measurements on various levels, i.e. can be viewed here: http://uk-air.defra.gov.uk/latest/currentlevels
column34: Very thorough database, various selection possibilities, however bulk data are not available.
column35: One has to know that the official stats don't help for detailed data as we are looking for here. I.e. not inside data.gov.uk and the likes. After that DEFRA's UK Air pretty quickly shows up.

column15: Electoral Commission
column18: Electoral Commission of the UK coordinates and organises the elections as a government department. Their data is a bit hidden under "Our work" / "Research" / "Electoral Data".
column20: The data is shared/re-used on the websites of various political parties
column24: Data on the more recent elections (EU 2014, Councils 2014) are available in both xlsx and csv formats, previous ones only as xlsx or xls, no clear pattern recognisable for time between 2010 and 2012, as of 2010 only xls.
column26: One dataset (xlsx) or zip of several csv datasets for the entire election available - this qualifies as raw/bulk.
column29: Open Government License 2.0
column31: 2014-09-15 (EU Election May 2014 - judging by the datas of the csv in the zip. I assume this was an update)
column33: After the elections, the time it took the to publish the preliminary and the final result cannot be found, no publication data or update time given.
column34: Rather sustainable. However, a scheme or small portal and a release calendar would be rather helpful.
column35: Altogether: Yes, even though finding the real election data is a bit difficult. When looking on the site at entry level, and going by "Find information by subject", the election information only features a PDF report. And a link to the BBC for election results [!]. The actual election data can be found under "Our work" / "Research" / "Electoral Data".

column15: Cabinet Office on behalf of the government
column18:
The government offers Contracts Finder as a service allowing to search for information about contracts worth over GBP 10,000 with the government and its agencies.
Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland are covered by their own dedicated public sector procurement websites.
column19:

Besides the general contract finder page local councils publish contract-related data on their websites (2)(3)
column24: There are different ways to access Contracts Finder data, i.e. activity summary + buyer group list; detailed reports - recent notices (last 40 days); detailed reports - older notices (monthly). rss feeds contain data for past 90 days.
column26: Monthly data ranges back until Jan 2011 - definitely qualifies as bulk.
column29: OGL
column34: Amount of data + easy access and good documentation make data offered quite sustainable.
column35: Via the Contracts Finder site, 'data feeds' featured several times on the landing page.

There are several government agencies that collect and share geographic data in Uruguay. These services are collected in the IDE website, run by AGESIC (Infraestructura de Datos Espaciales). Most websites share the same basic data and add specific layers of information, and include open datasets to download.

Ministry of Tourism and Sports (Ministerio de Turismo y Deportes) http://www.turismo.gub.uy/index.php/en/

The agency responsible for regulating Health services and maintaining both general and perfomance indicators datasets is the Ministry of Public Health (Ministerio de Salud Pública), mainly through the National Health Board (Junta Nacional de Salud - Junasa).

Information about health care providers and performance is also reported periodically (at the moment this survey was conducted 2013 data was about to be published: http://www.msp.gub.uy/noticia/rendici%C3%B3n-y-balance-durante-2013-snis-redujo-costo-de-%C3%B3rdenes-y-tickets-y-los-elimin%C3%B3-para)

column15:
Data about primary and secondary education performance in Uruguay is collected and maintained by several governmental actors, lacking a central unit that comprehensively aggregates and shares data. The closest to that is the National Institute for Evaluation of Education (Instituto Nacional de Evaluación Educativa - INEED - whose board is formed by members of the Ministry of Education and Culture, the National Education Administration and one representative of private institutions and one for the public University). 

Basic indicators data is collected and shared at the websites of the different institutions involved in the complex governance of education in Uruguay. Some of these are also posted at the websites of Office for Planning and Budget and the Ministry of Social Develpment (MIDES). These general datasets are usually posted in proprietary formats like Microsoft Excel. It is important to note that actual performance datasets that include microdata are collected but not publicly shared.

column15: The main governmental agency responsible for crime statistics is the Ministry of Interior, which maintains and online observatory where it publishes information in the form of periodic reports (annual and by six month period). These reports are in pdf format and refer to general aggregated data and indicators. Direct access to data at a more granular level is not public and may or not be collected. Additional information can be found at the "Seguridad ciudadana" section of the "Observatorio Social" of the Ministry of Social Development, where complementary data on some specific issues (e.g gender violence) can be found.
column20: No relevant third party sites found

column15: The main agencies in charge of emissions and other environmental data in Uruguay are the Ministry of Housing, Territorial Planning and Environment (Ministerio de Vivienda, Ordenamiento Territorial y Medio Ambiente -MVOTMA-)and the Ministry of Livestock, Agriculture and Fisheries (Ministerio de Ganadería, Agricultura y Pesca -MGAP-). Both minisitries have units directly in charge of data and publish it regularly at their websites. The MVOTMA site includes a few visualization tools for some topics like protected areas or coastal regions.The information available is usually in proprietary formats like excel or through annual reports in pdf form. Some selected indicators are also available at other general information websites, like the MIDES social observatory website (environment section) or the MDG reports.

column15: The agency in charge of this dataset is the Elections Court (Corte Electoral), which is the national elections authority. Information is comprehensive and shared, and the institution's website creates special sections and subsites for access to information when there are elections (this was the case at the moment this survey was conducted). It is possible to access the data online and in some cases registration is needed for live connections. The data is not published as Open Data though.

a few indicators regarding participation is available at the IDEA website in csv, machine readable formats: http://www.idea.int/es/uid/

column23: Most of the data is availalbe in HTML form, except the city council elections (https://catalogodatos.gub.uy/dataset/resultados-elecciones-concejos-vecinales)

column15:
The agency in charge of this information is the State Contracts and Purchases Agency (Agencia de Compras y Contrataciones del Estado), which depends of the Presidency of the Republic. The site includes an online query system and the information is publicly available there. A few datasets (mostly regarding procedures and standards) are available at the government open data catalog. Even though the full databases are not directly available online it is possible to program a bot (or do it one by one)and query the online service and get the data. 

The process of integration of public contracts and purchases in the system is ongoing but not yet complete, and some public organizations have been slow to adapt to it. This means that not every public contract and purchase is included in the system nowadays.

column18:
Citing the OKF Open Data Index: "In the US, corporate registration happens at the state level. The timeliness, availability, and licensing of this data varies among all 50 states. There is no federal dataset that contains all corporate registrations. It would be possible to create a unified open registry for all US corporations (even if only via aggregation from state ones) but this does not exist at this time."

Web Index Researcher: "I had a short Twitter-conversation with OpenCorporates and confirmed that there is still no dataset on a national level."

column15:
The most accessible system on awarded contracts appears to be USAspending.gov, run by the Office of Management and Budget.
For contract opportunities it's Federal Business Opportunities (FedBizOpps).
column18:
According to a report by the Congressional Research Service, the Federal government uses a variety fo acquisition systems, including Acquisition Central, Electronic Subcontracting Reporting System (eSRS), Federal Business Opportunities (FedBizOpps), Federal Funding Accountability and Transparency Act (FFATA) Portal, Federal Procurement Data System-Next Generation (FPDS-NG), Federal Awardee Performance and Integrity Information System (FAPIIS), FFATA Sub-Award Reporting System (FSRS), Interagency Contract Directory (ICD), Past Performance Information Retrieval System (PPIRS), System for Award Management (SAM), USAspending.gov, and Wage Determinations On-line (WDOL). This is not exactly easy to cope with if one is mainly looking for some easily accessible datasets. In addition, the report states: "Over the years, questions have been raised regarding the accuracy, completeness, and timeliness of the contract award data available from FPDS and its successor, FPDS-NG." (1)

The report features an overview of the acquisition systems on page 8 (2)

(1) L. Elaine Halchin: Transforming Government Acquisition Systems: Overview and Selected Issues, June 2013 - http://fas.org/sgp/crs/misc/R43111.pdf
(2) http://fas.org/sgp/crs/misc/R43111.pdf#8
column19:
https://www.fbo.gov/ - Federal Business Opportunities (FedBizOpps): Agencies post contract opportunities for goods or services expected to be higher than $25,000. 

www.usaspending.gov - Federal, including subcontract/subcontractor information on the Federal Funding Accountability and Transparency Act

www.fapiis.gov/fapiis/govt/datareports.jsp - Federal Awardee Performance and Integrity Information System: 
(Data on past performance only available to government officials)

sunshinereview.org/index.php/Proactive_Disclosure - Directory of State’s portals

checkbooknyc.com/contracts_landing/status/A/yeartype/B/year/114 - New York City, United States
column24:
The data can be downloaded in form of prime awards and sub-awards and allows filtering by agency, fiscal year(*), recipient state, place of performance state, and records submitted since. Also, the spending data can be selected by contracts, grants, loans, direct payments, insurance or other. 'contracts' is the only category directly relevant for our survey. Also the level of detail can be chosen between 'basic' and 'complete'. The amount of entries when selecting all contracts for 2014 with basic infos is very large. I had so slim down the time range to one week in order to retrieve less than 65.000 entries.

(*) Fiscal years start in October 1 and end in September 30, i.e. fiscal year 2014 ends on September 30, 2014.
column26: As the data can be downloaded in a "full" version, only having to download yearly datasets, but having to select nothing else, this does definitely qualify. The data is raw, a database equivalent.

column15:
According to the Law of Public Registry and Notarizing (Ley de Registro Público y del Notariado)(1)company registration should be done before State Business offices (Oficinas de Registro Mercantil). 

Nonetheless, the  Ministerio del Poder Popular para Industrias (2) runs the Management Integrated System for Industry and Commerce (Sistema Integral de Gestión para las Industrias y el Comercio) (3) in which companies must also register. 

Additionaly, the Ministerio del Poder Popular para el Comercio (4) via their office Fair Prices Superintendency (Superintendencia de Precios Justos)(5) runs the Unique Registry for People who develops economic activities  
Registro Único de Personas que desarrollan actividades económicas - RUPDAE)(6).  

However, none of this public offices make their data publicy available via internet.

column15:
The National Assembly publishes projects of law in legislative agenda as well as final text of approved laws. (1)
Just 9 laws appeared as approved in 2013, none from 2014 is published. Approved laws are published in .pdf format. 
Projects of law on legislative agenda are not longer available on the web. They used to be published until 2012. 

All enacted laws, as well as Executive government decrees must be published in the Gaceta Oficial. Official website for the Gaceta Oficial domain expired. Gaceta Oficial is printed every working day. 

Last update of the Gaceta Oficial within the National Assembly website was on March 21, 2014. (2)

The Tribunal Supremo de Justicia keeps publishing Gaceta Oficial text on .pdf format. (3) Last update was on June 6, 2014.

column16:
Must public transportantion services are provided by private independent vehicle owners or small cooperatives. Neither local or regional governments exercises quality control of such services. There is not work schedule that such providers are expected to comply. 

Subway services operated by national government company have been running out of schedule with frequent stoppages for several years now.

The municipality of Caracas provides a .png file showing the routes

column15:
The Banco Central de Venezuela (BCV) (1), the Instituto Nacional de Estadística (INE) (2) and the Centro Nacional de Comercio Exterior (CENCOEX) (3) must collect data on international trade. 

BCV publishes aggregated data on international trade. (4)
INE provides broken links to the supposedly existing data (5). It also provides a system to search for commercial exchange with different countries (6)
The recently created CENCOEX publishes in their webpage only national political news, no information on international  trade is published by this office.

column15:
In Vietnam, there is no definition "Land ownership", there is only "land usage right" (1). When you want to pay money to get the "land usage right", you have to go to the local office of the government and pay to see the map of registered land to know if it is legal to buy the rights or not. 

##Source: 

http://vietnamembassy-usa.org/basic-page/land-regulations  - No.1 Land Use Rights and Land Use Right Certificate
column18:
There are some official sources depending on provinces that you can track the data about land usage right in the area you need (1).  In other places, you have to go the local office to be able to see the exact information about land usage that relates the area that you are concerned about. 

##Sources: 

(1) such as in Ho Chi Minh City : http://www.planic.org.vn/district_map.php?act=sub_detail&sub_id=458&id=1  - Accessed 14th July 2014
or Ben Tre: http://113.163.94.8:8080/btgis/control  - Accessed 14th July 2014. But you can't find it on the official website of Ministry of Environment and Natural Resources: http://www.monre.gov.vn/ - Unable to access on 14th July 2014

column15:
The government collected the data about national budget, but not share to the public. The Center for Development and Integration (CDI), a non-governmental organization in Vietnam chosen for the survey, said the draft State budget of Vietnam had not been revealed to the public before it was passed by the National Assembly (NA) (1) 

On Open Budget Survey organized world-wide, question from 109-112, the Citizen Budget is not applied in Vietnam (2) but some information is now availabe on the Ministry of Finance Website

column18: There are very basic maps that are Yemen Geological Survey Mineral Resources Board publishes but they are mainly addressing information of concern to researchers involved in mineral and geology research. Other maps provided by the government are those of oil blocks meant to companies interested in oil exploration.
column19:
http://www.­ygsmrb.­org.­ye (Accessed June 19)

column23: Images embedded in flash or gifs or no links to data downloads at all.

column15: The only agency that holds this information is the Survey Authority and Land Registration of Yemen and it remains well underdeveloped when it comes to storing land data as it utilizes regular hand-written records that are not digitally stored.
column18: http://www.survey-authority.gov.ye/

column15: The Central Statisticcal Organization
column18: It gathers and maintains statistics datasets of various areas but provides most of its data in HTML or PDF format for manual exploration. In addition: Data about economics indicators is available in the official website of Ministry of Finances (http://www.mof.gov.ye/issues/financial-statistics-issues.html). Demographic indicators are available in the official website of Ministry of Public Health and Population (http://www.moh.gov.ye/arabic/reports_statistical.html). But these are not up to date.
column19:
http://www.cso-yemen.org/ (at the time of assessment, the website was suspended)
- economics indicators through Ministry of Finances http://www.mof.gov.ye/issues/financial-statistics-issues.html
- demographic indicators through Ministry of Public Health and Population http://www.moh.gov.ye/arabic/reports_statistical.html
column23: All documents on accessible websites are available as PDFs.

column15: The Ministry of Finances is the governmental entity that provides those budgets.
column18: Reports are incomplete as there is some information missing, such as defence and other budgets. And the reports are mostly in PDF format.
column23: The information is available as PDF.

column15: The Ministry of Finances
column18:
The data that is available is quite high-level data still: on a quarterly basis, a comparison of various indicators between expected and real, but no detailed spending.

http://www.mof.gov.ye/budget/final-accounts.html
http://www.mof.gov.ye/files/statistics/2014/56.pdf

column15: The Ministry of Industry and Trade
column18:
The list of company registers at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_company_registers#Yemen suggests Yemen has a company register provided by the Ministry of Industry and Trade - but this does not appear to be a compulsory register, only a voluntary listing of companies.

It provides means of inquiring about a particular company but has no spreadsheets with all the companies. Data available by a search request (Arabic language) in HTML format.
column23: One may be successful visualising a single web-based entry (HTML) at a time, with the proper keywords.

column15: The National Information Center
column18: The Center is a governmental agency that provides extensive information of regulations, legislation, ministries, and other information. It provides the information mainly as static HTML.
column23: The texts were available as static webpages.

column15: The Ministry of Transport
column16: There is no public transport system for buses and rail service. On the Ministry of Transport website (http://www.mot.gov.ye/), there's a link to the official website of the Instance in charge of Transport Management http://www.ltaa.gov.ye/mainltaa.php?action=sitescom which gives a list of transport companies like this one http://www.yemitco.com/contants.asp?CBT=1&SeIdN=1 but no transport timetables available.

column15: The Ministry of Industry and Trade has a section on international trade.
column18: There are only four subsections focusing on the period 2006-2010. The few available files are PDFs, static webpages (http://www.moit.gov.ye/moit/ar/node/288) and once as Excel sheet (http://www.moit.gov.ye/moit/sites/default/files/%20%D9%88%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D9%86%D8%AA%D8%AC%D8%A7%D8%AA2007_2008.xls). But it has been out of date in recent years.

column15: The Ministry of Public Health and Population.
column18: There is no dataset per se, just files in different formats and outdated.
column20: http://apps.who.int/gho/data/view.main.1900ALL?lang=en (but the data available here is not available on the Yemeni MoH website)
column23: The available statistical reports are available as PDFs only (http://www.moh.gov.ye/arabic/reports_statistical.html)

column15: The Ministry of Education
column18:
There is data collected by the Ministry of Education from schools about the performance of students, etc. but it is not shared anywhere on the web.
http://www.yemenmoe.net/

column15: Some of the data collected by the Ministry of Interior is provided online in the form of html text through the Crime Media Center.
column18: http://www.smc.gov.ye/ Only news are available, but no reports, no publications, no datasets.

column15: The Environmental Protection Agency
column18: Some information is shared by the Environmental Protection Agency but is abstract, limited in time and scope and is a one-page on a static webpage. Also, the Ministry of Minerals has some up-to-date news (http://www.mom.gov.ye/en/index.php?option=com_content&view=category&id=47&Itemid=34) but nothing on environment and sustainable development.
column23: The only available information is a static one-page on the agency's website.

column23:
http://web.scer.gov.ye/uploads/report_of_2012.pdf
The rare reports are available as PDFs only.

column15: The High Tender Board is the governmental agency responsible for providing data about public contracting.
column18:
http://htb.gov.ye/sh_cat.php?cat_id=151
http://htb.gov.ye/show_tender_.php?ten_id=163
The website is difficult to navigate, very scarce information is available.
column23: Each tender is available as a general description of the subject, funds engaged and various time-bound information (static HTML; ex. http://htb.gov.ye/show_tender_.php?ten_id=163), then the full-text is available as PDF (http://htb.gov.ye/documents/Tender49.2010%D8%B9%D8%B1%D8%A8%D9%8A.pdf)

column15: The survey department at the Ministry of Lands, Natural Resources and Environmental Protection (http://www.ministryoflands.gov.zm/index.php/survey-department). It is the survey department that is responsible for Mapping through Mapping Services Branch
column18: Topographic Maps(Scale 1:50,000) Atlas Sheets for Various scales and Street Maps (All Copperbelt towns, Lusaka, Livingstone & Kabwe)
column20: Only international sources such as Google Maps.

column15: The Ministry of Lands, Natural Resources and Environmental Protection. The Lands Department is responsible.
column18: Unknown as there is no land ownership data on the website of the Ministry. However, It is reported that The Ministry of Lands, Natural Resources and Environmental Protection embarked on the development of a new robust computerized Land Information System called the Zambia Integrated Land Management and Information System (ZILMIS). This is in an effort to replace the current semi-manual system called the Land Information Management System (LIMS) which has had major challenges as regards security, reliability, integrity and efficiency thereby not performing to the desired levels. The development of the new system commenced on 24th January 2013.

column15: The Central Statistical Office, Zambia
column18:
The data set is known as population and housing census. It includes demographic characteristics such as population by province, by sex, by religion, Marital status, education attained, Economic Characteristics,Fertility,Childhood,General and Maternal Mortality,Language and Ethinicity,Disability,Abinism
among other variables.
column23: Only available in pdf formats

column15: Ministry of Finance
column18: The data provides government expected incomes, expenditures on the various government agencies and ministries. The other information available on the website under the National budgets and on the Ministry of Finance Data Portal is inform of budget speeches with information on government.
column23: The data is only available in pdf formats

column15: Ministry of Finance
column18:
The information shows expenditures on the various sectors in Zambia. It shows expenditures against releases.

http://www.mofnp.gov.zm/index.php/accountant-generals-report/viewcategory/3-financial-reports provides some data, but only on a quarterly basis. 

The government expenditure is normally shown through the budget (1) as a forecasts and through such platforms as the public accounts committee (2)(3) meetings as well as live broadcasts of parliament proceedings through Parliament radio and other channels (3). No government open data is available.

##Sources
(1)Budget Bulletin 2013, Grant Thornton Zambia, 2013, 2013 budget Commentary, http://brendait.blogspot.com/2012/10/power-of-we-zambian-bloggers-network.html
(2) Interview with Machova Musanshi, Zambian Journalist, on 11th June, 2014, in Lusaka, Zambia
(3)Interview with Lloyd Mugala, Marketer, Tourism News, on 11th June, 2014 in Lusaka, Zambia

column15: Patents and Company Registration Agency under the Ministry of Commerce, Trade and Industry
column18:
A computer printout is issued  containing the following details:-

1.    Company or Business Name
2.    Date of incorporation or registration(for Buness Names)
3.    Registered office
4.    Postal address
5.    Nominal Capital and number of shares
6.    Type of the Company
7.    Financial year for a Company or Business Name
8.    Details of directors, partners or sole proprietors - these include their full names, nationality, National Registration or   Passport Number and their residential addresses.
9.    Details of shareholder and the number of shares held in a company

column15:
Zambia Police Services.

Crime control wings such as the Zambia police have the data on crime statistics, and while they at times are able to release information through press releases, they do not always provide the requested information in full. When the researcher asked for some traffic crime information, the police were able to provide the surrounding information, but could not disclose the other information. They could not even provide a clear explanation why they couldn’t give the other requested information.
column18: The Zambia Police Service website is not operating at the time of this research which makes it difficult to understand the details of information on crimes in the country - http://www.zambiapolice.gov.zm/

column15:
Ministry of Lands and Rural Resettlement (http://www.lands.gov.zw/) through the division of Land Information Management System.

Zimbabwe National Statistics Agency (Zimstat) (www.zimstat.co.zw)
column18:
The division of Land Information Management System is a department of the Ministry of Lands, Land Reform and Resettlement established to provide adequate Lands Information to the Agricultural sector. It is mandated to device a comprehensive land information management system for Zimbabwe (one stop shop for land information). 

The information is available with in the Ministry but not available online. However, there is a form also on the website that indicates the kind of information that Land beneficiaries should fill in order to be entered into the system - http://www.lands.gov.zw/land-beneficiary-form
column20: Data is not available from a third party

column15: Zimbabwe National Statistics Agency (Zimstat).
column18: The data set is known as Zimbabwe National Population Census. Whilst PDF reports are available from the National Statistics Agency, the agency website also provides a download of ZimDat, a version the DevInfo Software (http://www.devinfo.org/zimdat/libraries/aspx/home.aspx). This download is not documented on the website and comes as a 130Mb download, which contains data accessible through an online interface. Within the download is machine-readable data, but without in-depth knowledge of the DevInfo software it would be hard for an everyday user to extract.
column20: Data is available in the ZimDat tool, created using DevInfo's database tool, and also published on their website.
column24: The data can only be accessed by downloading a Windows only application and then either manually extracting information from an Access database, or using the software to locate and export particular data extracts.
column26: Bulk data can be extracted from the ZimDat tool, but only with directly accessing underlying files. A download of some data in CSV format is provided at http://www.devinfo.org/zimdat/libraries/aspx/home.aspx (third party) but this is only aggregate statistics.
column27: PDF reports and ZimDat are both provided free of charge.
column29: No licensing information is given. The ZimStat website states Copyright © 2010 ZIMSTAT - All Rights Reserved.
column34: There are only two data sets or information for 2002 and 2012. The ZimDat tools is not updated with 2012 Census data.
column35: Whilst basic information can easily be found on Zimbabwe National Statistics Agency website under population and demography link, the ZimDat system is not documented. The online access to data provided by DevInfo is not linked to from the ZimDat websites.

column18:
The Zimbabwe Republic Police is responsible for sharing information on crimes statistics. However, there is no website for the agency

The Zimbabwe National Statistics Agency publishes crimes statistics through the Zimbabwe Prisons and Correctional Services (ZPCS) collects information on prisons admissions and discharges on a monthly basis. Data are collected using the Admissions and Discharge/Release questionnaires. The information is used to measure and assess changes in crime trends and prison population characteristics.  The crimes statistics is characterized by crimes by age, reliegion of belief, sex, marital status, etc
